column1: This book is far from believable. But never the less a good read. I was able to put it down and took a few days to read it
column2: instead of my normal one to two days. She starts plot lines and does not follow through on them. And the flow of time from chapter to chapter is very erratic.   The first chapter of this book is very well written. There is a wonderful depiction of village life in tribal India. I felt as if I was there. It makes you want to read the rest of the book.  But this level of writing is not carried through. I also found that the quick glimpse of high tech computer firms corporate backstabbing was very accurate. And the choices they make on whom to fire and keep was right on target. It made me remember why I retired from the work force before I was at the age of forty without any regret and never looked back.  The book does have romance and intrigue. But
column3: the characters are too atypical and our heroine is too perfect. The author does try to let us into the view of a bicultural heritage in today's world. She just seemed to not know how to show is the journey.

column1: I rented this movie because I really adore the two lead actors.  However
column2: although they do the best they can
column3: there is no saving this banal
column4: movie of the week-esque movie.  There are a couple of nice moments
column5: most notably when D'Onofrio's character talks about his father and about his love of football.  Other than that
column6: the story seems to be cobbled together from many other "uplifting" movies.  At times
column7: you can not only guess what will happen next
column8: but can guess what the exact line will be.  Football hero becomes self-pitying after an accident leaves him blind (and unable to satisfy his cheap girlfriend in the sack--which she exposes in a tell-all book).  His tutor from school shows up
column9: himself in a wheelchair
column10: and pops this crazy idea to enter a whitewater rafting race.  Even though he professes to have it all together and is all rah-rah
column11: he still feels his own sadness that his dreams of being a dentist were dashed by a drunk driver.  But first--you knew it!--they have to learn to trust each other.  This involves whacky stunts.  The two drive to the race
column12: having adventures
column13: learning about themselves and each other
column14: suprising locals with can-do spirit.  Each scene seems to end with the two sharing a warm laugh in the fuzzy sunset.  Each person they run into is nutty.  And even though I said I liked this
column15: the lines from the scene where Olee talks about his dad seem to practically be directly from "The Breakfast Club" where the jock talks emotionally about his dad.  Only the commitment of Hines and D'Onofrio keep this one from getting no stars at all.  So to recap: Person who's cocky and beloved for his physical prowess loses it and feels sorry for himself? Check. That person has one last chance to hear the chanting of the crowd and relive the glory? Check. Another person who's been down that same road of self-pity and redemption comes along to save him? Check. Two men bond on the road and endure colorful locals? Yup. Student becomes teacher? Yes. Locals try to keep them down? Check. Other dreamers lend a hand? Drunk driving? Boy stunted emotionally by father? Bathroom humor? Improbable competition set up to prove worth of the outsiders
column16: and won to stirring music and cheers? All those who've been touched by the quest and who we've met along the way show up at the end? Suprise ending that is supposed to warm your heart and teach you what's really important?  Yes
column17: yes
column18: yes

Instead of being titled "property and freedom
column2: it should be titled property and power." Pipes was a prominent old cold-war apologist for American capitalism
column3: and you can tell that he is still trapped in his little world of false-dichotomy.   Pipes overall argument is contrived
column4: and with the exception of his knowledge of Russian history
column5: superficial. Most of his time is spent criticizing the Stalinist Soviet Union
column6: while at the same time lacking any thoughtful rebuttal to Marx's critique of capitalism.  His title claim
column7: that freedom cannot exist without private property
column8: is weak philosophically and logically. He has poor insight into the nature of freedom and presonal responsibilty. He would really benefit by reading some Sartre or Nietzche
column9: before trying to describe his own made up idea freedom. His attempts to link economic thought with philosophy and history fail miserably. He barely exposes the actual writings of Marx. This is incredibly unfortuante since most "real-world" capitalists
column10: such as wealthy Wall street brokers
column11: know that Marx understood capitalism better than any of its supporters. His philosophical support is all anecdotal with no real thoughtful analysis. His historical summary
column12: although detailed with Russia
column13: leaves much to be desired. He fails to discuss slavery
column14: prostitution
column15: or even slumlords
column16: all which flourish under American capitalism.   Although some might find his credentials enough to accept his flimsy argument
column17: I for one was greatly disappointed. I realize that property is linked to power
column18: but freedom is something completely different.   I'm sure many right-wing folks will look past all of this flaws in this books and embrace it. I'm sure the paternalistic allure of an established Harvard professor will cause some to avoid challenging the views in his book.    But I'm not trying to convince those people. Look past the credentials
column19: the excessive use of footnotes to appear more "academic" ( a clear sign of a writer who is insecure of his own beliefs!)
column20: and the comfort of someone who agrees with your agenda
column21: and you will discover shallow puerile nonsense

Instead of being named "AC and the Age of Steel
column2: it should have been named The Age of Steel with Andrew Carnegie."  This documentary is more about steel than this famous rich guy.  They don't even bring up Carnegie until one-fifth of the way into the work.  They show about two photos of him and that's all.  You never learn if he went to college
column3: what charities he supported
column4: or how he died.  They show a photo of Carnegie with a man I believe to be Booker T. Washington.  Did Carnegie support Black colleges or other African-American causes of the time?  This work never answers:  all it does is focus on steel.  I can't believe that the History Channel actually thought a marketable number of people would want to know about that.  Leave that boring stuff in an engineering classroom!  I liked that the interviewees came from a diverse range of universities in the South and North.  I hate that I'm buying into ideas that only "great men" are worthy of historical works.  But still
column5: yawn!  I was left very disappointed

column1: I agree with all of the other reviews about this tent and its durability

column1: This is the story of Sheriff Bell
column2: an insufferable dullard who won't shut up about how criminals these days are really evil (as opposed to all the lovely ones he knew of when growing up?).   He's also a world-class boaster
column3: never going more than a few pages without telling us how fantastic is wife Loretta is. The same Loretta who spends most of her time baking for or writing to evil criminals -- which tells me all I need to know about that marriage.  The yakkity-yakking doesn't stop there. An even bigger gas-bag is Chigurh
column4: the motor-mouthed murderer. In fact
column5: he kills people twice. Before he shoots 'em
column6: he bores 'em to death. His weapon of choice: Lectures about coins. (His final kill took so long
column7: I had to restrain myself from flingling the book across the train carriage.)  On the technical front
column8: McCarthy does not structure the drama in the Classical way. He chose the Boring way. The majority of scenes end exactly as you expect and only one character (Moss) has a believable goal. McCarthy also omits the obligatory final scene
column9: between Chigurh and his prey Moss
column10: which was the only reason I kept reading the book. No doubt this is to defy the expectations of the reader. Expectations that this might turn out to be a decent story
column11: in my case.   What's more
column12: Sheriff Bell has no scenes with either Chigurh or Moss
column13: making him a narrator with zero personal stake in the action. Because McCarthy writes good
column14: visual dialogue
column15: he gets away with an inconsequntial narrator for the first half of the story. But when the man on the run (Moss) exits the story
column16: there is no other character to invest in
column17: so the plot grinds to a halt. McCarthy cannot resusitate it because there is no connection whatever between the two remaining main players.  So
column18: does McCarthy put us out of our misery? No. Sheriff Bell waffles on for pages and pages about Vietnam
column19: not unlike John Goodman's character Walter in the Big Lebowski. And that's it.  My verdict: I hope Loretta runs away with a criminal. Preferably one of them new evil ones

column1: Something like 15 years ago
column2: I ran across the first three annual volumes of this anthology at a science fiction and fantasy bookstore.  Ever since
column3: I've eagerly looked forward to every volume
column4: for weeks or months ahead of publication.  Once received
column5: each yielded a couple of weeks of daily reading treat.  I admit
column6: since I dislike horror
column7: I've always wished that the horror had been spun off into a separate volume.  Still
column8: Ellen Datlow's taste in horror is pretty sophisticated
column9: some of it being closer to dark fantasy
column10: which I do like.  I always read the horror last.  But Terri Windling's fantasy selection more than made up for the horror content of the volume.  All those stories culled from "literary" magazines I never read (as being too modern and New-Yorky) for my taste.  And her roundups/brief reviews of new fantasy books!  I've discovered so many "mainstream" books and authors not marketed as fantasy from Windling's reviews.  Since the inception of Amazon
column11: every roundup had me rushing to put at least ten more books in my shopping cart.  Unfortunately
column12: this is probably the last annual volume I'll ever buy.  The new team editing the fantasy content
column13: Kelly Link and Gavin Grant
column14: just are not up to Windling's standards.  First
column15: in both the story selection and the roundups
column16: it seems that they did not read nearly as wide a range of sources as Windling did. Second
column17: their selections were lackluster.  The stories I really liked I'd already read in major fantasy magazines. The others were . . . sort of all right.  Mildly interesting.  But not worth that many pages.  I discovered one book worth buying in the review roundups
column18: which were also lackluster.    All in all
column19: the uninteresting fantasy combined with that much horror
column20: meant that the two weeks' delight I'd experienced for so many years
column21: turned into a month-long slog
column22: with me frequently counting stories (I don't read them in order) to see if I was finally almost done with the thing yet.  Let's hope there's another change of editors soon.  And maybe
column23: just maybe
column24: they'll put the horror in a separate anthology
column25: where it belongs

I'm not surprised that someone with very little exposure to philosophical thought would find the arguments of this book convincing. The authors do a great job of employing misleading statistics and frequently resort to logical fallacies (petitio principii
column2: mainly) in their arguments. This book is great if you want an anti-capitalist screed
column3: but it fails miserably as an impartial analysis of business ethics. Like ssaber
column4: I was disappointed to find a three page "defense" of capitalism and a ten page attack of it in Chapter 4
column5: "The Nature of Capitalism." The authors include the views of a wide range of notable experts in this section
column6: including but not limited to Karl Marx
column7: George Soros
column8: and Bertold Brecht (yeah
column9: now there's a real authority on the subject). Why not include Sean Penn while you're at it
column10: guys? I wasn't surprised to find that they'd skipped over real economists like Keynes
column11: Hayek
column12: and Friedman.

column4: who receives a strange insect in the mail.  Unknowing to her the bug bites her hot girlfriend's ear and the ear swells up super fugly and squirts puss.  Ida never notices this mutation even after days of off screen (boo!!!) lovemaking.  What I just described took 40 minutes of screen time.  [Spoilers]  The last 20 minutes with its grand total body count of two (boo!!!) isn't much better
column5: Ida discovers that her hot girlfriend has been taken over by the insect and has murdered the landlady.  The hot girlfriend then kills a friend of Ida's and distracts her while the bug sticks his icky thing in Ida's ear.  How exciting.    Here are just a few of my problems with this story: Why waste so much time with Ida and her hot girlfriend hooking up?  Why not just have them together from the beginning?  Why make such a huge deal out of them being lesbians?  Do entomologists really have bugs crawling out of their clothes at all times?  The body count is two.  Why waste time with the pointless revenge subplot?  Ida doesn't notice her hot girlfriend shooting pus out of her ear

column1: That Robert Coles' heart is in the right place and that his experience working with children is extensive
column2: no one can dispute.  But his writing is characterized by wordiness - even chattiness - and it undermines the serious nature of his topic. Perhaps the loose writing style is an attempt to make the book appeal to "every parent
column3:
- and not just educators - but instead it renders the whole work laborious and permeated with a condescending, patronizing tone. In the current political culture, a book on the moral life of children written by an educator of Coles' calibre would be expected to nail a spot on the N.Y. Times bestseller list for weeks, if not years.  The fact that less than two years after publication I picked up a hard cover copy at a book clearance for 75% off is a testimony to lazy editorship more than anything else. What a huge loss for our society

column1: It's not easy to criticize this book
column2: because it is beautifully written and captures something tragic and poignant and important:  the emotional trials and conflicts of a spunky twelve year old girl who is coming of age in a world that doesn't understand her.  But McCullers' darker undercurrents taint the book.  Threaded throughout are elements of sexual perversity
column3: terrible sexual boundaries with children
column4: and hints at pedophilia
column5: leading me to question strongly what in the world happened to Carson McCullers when she was a little girl.  Furthermore
column6: the perversity often pops up in a disjointed way that adds nothing to the book's power
column7: and thus reads largely as gratuitous.  A few examples from the book - a book which I did not finish because I didn't trust where its author was taking me:  1) The main character
column8: a pubescent twelve year old girl who is nearly five-foot six
column9: has spent her whole life up till now sleeping in the bed with her widowed and single father
column10: until he looks at her one day and realizes she's "a great big long-legged twelve year old" - McCullers leaves exactly what he means to our imagination - and kicks her out of bed.  2) The girl's best friend is a six year old boy
column11: whom she bullies and torments
column12: and then basically forces to spend the night with her in her bed.  McCullers makes a point of showing how they change their clothes for bed in the same room - "with their backs turned to each other" - and then get in bed together.  Once the little boy is asleep the girl
column13: who is two months away from turning thirteen
column14: rubs his bare stomach with her hand
column15: licks him behind his ear
column16: and then nuzzles up to him.  (Also
column17: imagine if their genders were reversed!)  3) The father takes a married couple as boarders in the house
column18: but the girl - then age nine - walks in on them doing something overtly sexual with the door left purposefully open.  McCullers leaves it to the readers' imagination what her little protagonist viewed.  4) McCullers talks about the girl character
column19: age twelve
column20: having had sex with a neighborhood boy.  Again
column21: she gets vague on details
column22: but why is she sharing even this much?  If you were to remove the literary style and add a scant few more details
column23: you would have child pornography.  5) Eventually the girl changes her name
column24: wears an adult dress that makes her look much older - and goes out on the town and meets a visiting adult soldier.  He comes onto her sexually - though stops only because others come into the bar where he is giving her alcohol.  One is only left to wonder where the book will go from here.  Because this book was written in the 1940s the author can get away with it - and perhaps also because she's a female author - but really
column25: it's disturbing and perverse

column1: This book is written in the guise of a journal Anne Boleyn completes while awaiting her execution.   To anyone who's read a Jean Plaidy novel in which Henry VIII figures
column2: it should come as no surprise that she continued her crude portrayal of the legendary king in this book.  Henry is portrayed as a fat
column3: beady-eyed
column4: petulant
column5: lustful
column6: vulgar and spoiled child.  (Some of this must have basis in history
column7: since other writers have used the lustful and fat approach.)  He is given no depth
column8: no redeeming qualities; he is clearly The Villain Of The Piece.  It's a disappointment
column9: but not a major one if you've already read other works about the mighty monarch.  Your memory will be able to fill in a more well-rounded Henry.  (See especially Margaret George's "The Autobiography of Henry VIII
column10: with Notes by His Fool
column11: Will Somers.")  But Plaidy's treatment of Anne Boleyn is what surprised and shocked me.  Henry's second wife has generally been accepted throughout history as an adulterous woman who may or may not have been "a witch" but who certainly behaved more wickedly than a Queen would be expected to...a woman who was more desirous of the approving glances of men than of pleasing her husband or attending to affairs of state.  A woman who stopped at nothing to get her own way and assumed she could sweet-talk her way out of punishment.  But Plaidy paints her as a total innocent
column12: a sweet girl who is completely unaware of the King's regard.  Apparently for the years when Henry is pursuing Anne
column13: she is simply mooning about Hever Castle in the company of her stepmother
column14: keeping house
column15: or else being a maid of honor to then-Queen Katharine of Aragon - oblivious to the "mad pursuit" of her by Henry.  Even after they are married
column16: Plaidy's Anne is a happy
column17: cheerful woman who wants only to bear Henry a son.  The notorious scandal which preceded Anne's beheading (a scandal which affirmed that Anne slept with several gentlemen of the court
column18: including her own brother) is glossed over
column19: garnering only a quick mention at the end - with of course Anne's bewilderment at the news that she's to be beheaded for this.    I can't tell if Plaidy genuinely believes that Anne was innocent of any scandal
column20: or if she's being gently
column21: subtly mocking of the reader (and therefore of Henry VIII).  The pages of the "journal" mention Anne's astonishment at such a scandal but Anne
column22: writing
column23: never actually denies that the adultery happened.  She merely muses
column24: as a detached observer
column25: at the strangeness of the scandal.   However
column26: none of Plaidy's books to date have shown much subtlety
column27: so I assume Anne is meant to be portrayed as a total innocent whose end was manufactured for Henry's marital benefit.  If you don't already know the history behind Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn
column28: this book may not make much sense to you.  Since Henry is a minor character
column29: we are given none of the historical happenings beyond a few major things (the meeting at the Field of Cloth of Gold
column30: for example) told through Anne's eyes.  If you want to know more about Anne
column31: I recommend Ms. George's book mentioned above.

column1: I have been a huge fan of Michael Crichton for about 25 years.  However
column2: this book is misleading and dangerous.  Almost every respectable scientist in the world now agrees that global warming is real and that we are greatly accelerating this problem (except some scientists affiliated with the petroleum and automobile industries).    Writing a book that disputes global warming would be like writing a book that disputes the holocaust - Mr. Crichton could just as easily have written a book about how the holocaust did not really happen
column3: and provide plenty of "references" to support this premise.  Tragically
column4: in the long term
column5: global warming could be far more destructive than even the holocaust.    I hope that someday Mr. Crichton recognizes that
column6: in addition to his enormous talent for entertaining
column7: he has enormous influence on people's thoughts and actions through his books.  There is a quote: "With great power comes great responsibility."  But in this case it would seem: "With great power comes great profit at the expense of the planet.

column1: There certainly are many ways in which maternity care in the USA could be improved.  But this author's recommendations are not among them.  Even an open-minded person is put off by a great deal of plain old misinformation in this book.  For example
column2: an epidural does not (as claimed in the book) involve sticking a needle in the spinal cord - YOUCH!  Nor do women who have epidurals have more back pain afterwards than women who do not have epidurals.  Because it's the pregnancy stupid!  The book winds up being a colossal straw man.  Maybe someone else will write a truthful book incorporating factual information
column3: rational analyses and sensible suggestions for improvement

column1: In his introduction
column2: the author attempts vainly to put Merrill in the same category as Morgan and other great financiers. The problem is that he was not a financier

column4: Mr. Perkins did not seem to understand his topic very well. He constantly refers to the backroom at Merrill as "backstage." Did anyone ever research a topic so poorly? Whether Merrill deserves a full fledged biography still remains unclear after reading this amateurish attempt

column1: This book is as worthless for research as "The Da Vinci Code." I was particularly shocked at the authors' decision to ignore the fact that Tycho was an unbearable snob
column2: a petty despot and a complete boor in order to portray Kepler in the worst possible light. If Tycho was indeed poisoned
column3: it may have been by one of the hoodlums in his family or one of the many powerful nobles he snubbed. Although it is common to sacrifice the innocent in the interest of sensationalism
column4: this pseudo-historical account
column5: with its extensive bibliography
column6: truly sinks to new lows in selective revelation. The cynical allusion to Kepler's religious ambivalence is the product of the post-modern approach to religion
column7: where
column8: for instance
column9: Catholics get divorced and hope for the best. It is clear from his writings that Kepler took his religious commitments seriously and was genuinely hurt by what he called the un-Christian attitudes between the brothers in Christ.  The decision to overlook this along with other well documented information that calls Tycho's character into question (for instance the horrors of his treatment of the Hveen population or his routine snubbing of Christian IV) and reveals Kepler as a man of conscience falls somewhere between irresponsible and slanderous.

column1: A very disappointing book
column2: and again
column3: makes me very wary of any item on a "New York Times Best Seller List" or any other list
column4: and really any big name reviewer recommendation.  This book has one 50 page chapter which is excellent - the recap of the Thompson "Shot heard around the world" homerun. If you are a baseball fan as I am
column5: that (barely) made the book worthwhile. The other 700 pages are disjoint
column6: incomprehensible
column7: and really trivial. You come away thinking "I really don't care bout this stuff" - I don't care about the dynamics of trash
column8: about J Edgar Hoover's bathroom habits
column9: Klara Sax's artistic depression and annoying infatuations about roof tops
column10: about characters that just don't have much depth to really care about. At the end
column11: even potentially interesting characters like Albert (the one on the baseball quest) become hard to bear. The whole book in fact had the feel of going to a senior citizen home.  I read this book
column12: as perhaps others did

column14: some interesting tidbits here and there about how life used to be in the 50's (fear of nuclear weapons
column15: duck and cover classroom exercies)
column16: and a lot of knowledge about the trash business.   The "masterful" epilogue
column17: as other reviewers call it
column18: really does no justice to a reader who has spent so much time toiling over Delillo's ragtag story telling. I am ok with stream of consciousness writing
column19: or nonchronological chapters
column20: or even random chapters
column21: but the methods used in thsi book served no purpose other than to further make the reading difficult.   Was this book about how mundane our lives are versus the bigger things that occur around us? Or how each of us is on an individual quest? Or that the 50's-60's-70's-80's were just years of fear
column22: and the 90's are years of greed? I am still unsure
column23: I still don't think any of these themes came across well.  Please - not pretending to be a sophisticate
column24: intellectual
column25: or professional critic - but this book is really not worth the time or effort. You can be staisfied by a number of other books
column26: including the "The Corrections" by Franzen or "The Cold Six Thousand" by Ellroy  which cover a similar period or similar themes and do not make you so frustrated or disappointed at the end.  Read the first chapter
column27: then put the book down or you will be sorely disappointed and have wasted an awful lot of time.

column1: Goldman takes one of baseball's most entertaining characters and somehow manages to present us a story as lifeless as a pine tar rag.  There is no organizing theme to this narrative.  Although the  chapters are presented chronologically (playing career
column2: managing in Brooklyn
column3: then Boston)
column4: the anectodes skip around in an unorganized way -- making it hard to keep track of what is happening when
column5: or why we should care.  Here's what's interesting: - Casey Stengel played for John McGraw
column6: and they had a close relationship that amounted to McGraw willingly tutoring and nuturing Stengel's active mind.  McGraw was an important mentor to Stengel
column7: as a faculty advisor is an important mentor to a graduate student.  (McGraw's influence among 20th century managers has been well documented by Bill James). - Casey was instrumental in shaping Billy Martin's playing career
column8: both with the Oaks in the PCL and with the Yankees. But there are important differences between Stengel and Martin's approach to managing (although this is never discussed). - Casey managed some incrediblly bad teams (Boston Braves
column9: NY Mets) and some incrediblly good ones.  And he liked to platoon players
column10: use his bench
column11: and valued multi-positional players that increased his decision-making flexibility.  On his best teams was able to rely on a few switch-hitters or star hitters that allowed him to save his platoon match-ups for players with reserve or part-time roles.  However
column12: this rarely (if ever) was extended to pitchers
column13: whom he constantly moved in and out of different roles regardless of their talent level.  What we don't read about in this book is how managers that came after Stengel also employed these kinds of techniques.  Whitey Herzog (for example) valued multi-positional players.  Earl Weaver built active benches with situational hitters around a few switch-hitting or star regulars (as did Herzog) and used complez defensive and offensive platoons.  There is a good anecdote or two in the text
column14: but this is not the best source for reader's looking for funny Stengel stories.  At worst
column15: this book merely reinforces the idea that baseball players are little more than Strat-o-matic cards to be shuffled in and out of the line up to manipulate probability distributions.  Upon finishing the book
column16: we are left with little idea of how Casey actually liked to built his teams
column17: communicate with players
column18: solve problems or provide leadership.  We are told Stengel was (and considered himself) a good teacher
column19: but we don't really know what Stengel was trying to teach
column20: which is disappointing

column1: Searching For Caleb had a new setting every five pages
column2: family members who walked out and wouldn't have come back until they were "kidnapped"
column3: and chaotic events that led to a suicide
column4: all of which made this book interesting in an unusual way. This book is first set on a train going to New York City in the year of 1972. Then the scene changes to Cairo Mill
column5: Maryland. Suddenly it changes to Baltimore
column6: Maryland in the 1800's. A bit later it changes to Baltimore in 1980. Anne Tyler told most of the story in Maryland
column7: but at the end
column8: she changes to Louisiana. The story was about the Peck family
column9: which was a very sophisticated family. Wealthy
column10: respectable
column11: self-involved
column12: they always wore hats.  Even the little girls never went out of the house without a hat on. Basically the story was about Daniel Peck's search for his brother
column13: Caleb
column14: who walked off in 1912. It was also about his granddaughter Justine Peck's realization that she will never be the Peck that she always dreamed to be. The concept of this book
column15: then
column16: is finding oneself. Daniel Peck's main conflict was evident in his search for Caleb. When Caleb was in his twenties he just walked out on the family and didn't return or make contact with any family member. The search started when Daniel moved in with Duncan and Justine Peck. Daniel spent years researching and visiting people who might have known Caleb. He would visit people that were Caleb's friends or appeared in pictures with Caleb. Unfortunately
column17: he had absolutely no luck. So when Daniel's birthday came
column18: his oldest son "Two" hired him a private investigator to search for Caleb. The private investigator headed straight to work asking questions. He found out that when Caleb was younger all one would have to do to find Caleb was "Hold still a minute and listen." He found out how Caleb loved music. He also went searching to Caleb's home in Baltimore.  Then the private investigator learned where Caleb was just outside of New Orleans
column19: Louisiana. The private investigator told the Pecks this but before Daniel could meet Caleb
column20: Daniel died of a heart attack. This book was draining yet funny; mostly draining. The hardest part was keeping track of what part the story was in
column21: whether the past or the present.  Also the Peck family was absolutely insane. Actually two cousins ended up married to each other. That caused so much chaos that a separation
column22: a disowning and a suicide happened over the event. Then Justine and Duncan were constantly moving because Duncan would become restless and wanted a change. Justine just went along very easily but Meg
column23: their daughter
column24: hated moving. She locked herself in the bathroom a few times.  Daniel did not begin looking for his brother for practically 30 years after Caleb walked out. The comical parts were the best. For instance
column25: all the time that Daniel was searching for Caleb his old maid knew right where Caleb was. When Caleb left
column26: he had told her where he was going. Yet she never told anyone because no one ever asked her. In addition
column27: Duncan would cut out newspaper clippings and stick them to things.  To the old Ford that the door was torn off he stuck a clipping that said "Wouldn't you rather have a Buick?". When Meg bought an expensive dress
column28: his cut out was "Have you ever had a bad time in Levi's?" One of Justine's neighbor was divorced and the father of her child who had no visiting rights would come and take the daughter. The mother would scream and shout about her daughter being kidnapped
column29: yet every night the father brought the child home safe and sound. This book was very interesting
column30: but a strange kind of interesting.  It never really caught my attention; rather it often put me to sleep.  It was summer reading
column31: the kind you get on a book list.  I would suggest it to people if they didn't really have anything else to read. But some will like it. I found it too scattered in place and time and too slow moving.

column1: I was looking forward to the arrival of this bike so much
column2: I thought it was going to be a great way to burn calories while doing just about anything. But when I tried it I discovered 2 things. First off your legs have to be at a 90 degree angle in order to pedal without it moving all over the place (which means you have to have an adjustable office chair or put phone books on a normal one). And when I finally get settled on it no matter how hard of a setting it's on it only burns about a calorie a minute.   This bike might be great for arm workouts because it doesn't move as much on the table and it can offer a lot of resistance (though I only tried it for a few minutes) but definitely not for your legs

column1: The installation of this printer went very well.  However
column2: after installing the printer my computer began running EXTREMELY slow.  I checked and it was using 100% of the CPU.  I stopped all the processes associated with this printer and my speed returned to normal.  I contacted HP and they said it is a known problem and they are working on it (that was six months ago).  They still are working on it.  HP's solution is to install the print driver only (so you cannot use the scan or fax feature) until they write new software for this printer.  They should have recalled the printer since it doesn't work properly.  DO NOT PURCHASE THIS PRINTER!!!

The writer tries to generalize from the experience of four great statesmen in war times to make a conclusion that politicians should tell generals what to do!   I think this book is political biased.   Say if I was to reverse the equation and generalize from the experience of four great generals to make a conclusion that generals should tell statesmen what to do! Would the writer agree with me?   I could also write a few essays where democratic leaders just left his military leaders to do their job and the military leaders did a very good job eg  prime minister Eshkol  of Israel in the six day war and the Indian Prime Minister Mrs. Indian Gandhi in December 1971 in the Indian Pakistan war. Is the conclusion now that statesmen should stay out of the actual war.   Also I should stress is that most people are not *great*. To try to generalize from a few great men is a very dangerous experience. Great men by their nature are gifted and unusual.
Although the arrival/condition of the book was perfect
column2: the content was very limited.  I learned nothing new and feel I wasted my money.  My parrot is still obnoxious.  I had so hoped I would learn techniques to change his behavior

column1: I'm not a hard core Dean Koontz fan but I have read a few of his novels and enjoyed most of them (at least enough to pick up another from time to time)   Until now.   I've always found Koontz to be heavy handed as an author and 'The Taking' is about as subtle as a hand grenade. We get it - people are selfish and have lost sight of what is important in life. They should pay more attention to their children and love their dogs.   The preachy tone to the novel reaches a crescendo with a corny 'Noah's Arc' ending. This the worst novel I've read in a long time - and may be the last Dean Koontz novel I'll ever read.

Based on a true story?  If this is true then it is more horrible than being a fictional fantasy.  Did anyone witness this woman being raped?  People are just going on a murder's word that she was rape by these men.  I made two previous attempts to try to explain my point but as I started reading the other reviews I found one that explains everything I was trying to say.  One review stated the following:  I gave this 5 stars because men who rape women deserve an awful death.  Why?  When is it justifiable for a man to take revenge by killing a woman?  This movie was a fantasy and I feel sorry for a person who thinks it represent reality.  To state that anyone should have the right to take the law into his or her own hands is a crime.  To defend your self is one thing but to intentionally want to kill is simply murder.  The fictional female character (not the actor) in that story should be sent to prison for life for her alone deciding to be the Judge

 I'm a baseball fanatic, and have read other books like this, esp. Bill James Historical Abstract.  This book doesn't come close.  Kalb's ratings are generally pretty good but the writing is sort of mediocre and his reliance on the clown princes of baseball Broadcasting (McCarver and Buck) just completely destroys any pretense of integrity.  As Lewis says in MOneyball, most of what the average fan learns about baseball is bull-----, and most of it is from broadcasters.  I do not know anyone who listens to Mc and Buck who doesn't marvel at their stupidity, so using them to bolster an argument about who's best is pretty feeble.  OK reading for a trip or airplane trip but not especially well done 
 It seems to be a thinly veiled attempt to capitalize on the success of the Da Vinci Code. And just in case you missed it, there are several references too! The plot is wafer thin....who on earth would expend money and effort to simply chase a 4000-year old dream? All situations seemed to be too easily contrived and coincidental. Traps built several thousand years ago continue to work with the efficiency of a Swiss watch. Reilly thinks he's writing to a bunch of school kids.....exclamations, sound effects and hyphenated actions abound! Too obviously, the protagonists (Lily and West) have genius-level IQs and crack codes like you and I would crack our knuckles. The heroes have unfettered access to almost everything. Save yourself money and time .... stay away from this book

 Mr. Goodman and his coauthor have taken the ills of the gambling industry and provided a snapshot-like, journalistic and moralistic view of the problems.  The authors never address the other side of the story about this industry; the job and business formation, the enjoyment the majority of the gaming public gets from gambling, and the considerable revenues that state and local governments receive from taxation and the distribution of employee's income.    There are no researchers who rigorously study gambling and risk-taking who support the unbalanced approach that Mr. Goodman has taken in the book. To further clarify the situation, Mr. Goodman has never tried to published a study or paper in this area that would be reviewed by experts in the field.    In short, the book is good journalism but unbalanced and shoddy research.  This is great stuff for further inflaming the passion of the anti-gambling public and for sound bites, but it is not to be used for policy preparation/analysis or for a general understanding of the topic

column1: This brief novel offers a rather pointless speculative fiction take on Conrad's Heart of Darkness. A ridiculous and under-explained premise is used to prop up some equally under-explained ruminations from Ballard on the human condition and spirituality. Here the action takes place in an African jungle that is becoming crystallized
column2: as all objects slowly become encrusted with luminous jewels. Ballard doesn't explain how this process works except for some weak references to the "crystallized" time and space aspects of relativity. This implausible premise leads to curious changes in the people who also find themselves crystallized
column3: with some sort of inner peace and spiritual fulfillment being found in the process
column4: though Ballard leaves this aspect of the story anemic as well
column5: other than some flimsy philosophical ramblings. Meanwhile
column6: the action of the story mostly involves a pointless chase sequence connected to a blood feud between two shallow supporting characters
column7: which is never resolved within the story. Add to all of this the book's outdated colonialist conceptions of the third world and its inhabitants
column8: and the weak premise and theme of this novel retreat further into the crystal haze. [~doomsdayer520~

column1: A review states the Mark Noll "loves God and loves academics".  In spite of his very impressive collection of books on religion
column2: I feel he loves academics more.  This book is lifeless and seems to lack respect for 19th century religion and religious thought.  The prose is for academicians.  At no time will the author use a ten-letter word when he can find a twenty-letter one.  This is a book about religious intellectuals
column3: saying very little about how the people felt or what they were hearing at services.  We move from one essays or debate or article to another
column4: with little development or effort to access the impact of the item.  A problem could be that these items did not make a real impact
column5: being nothing more than talking points on the road to war.  The author interjects his views and beliefs constantly
column6: which seem very 21st century and totally out of place.  In an effort to "be inclusive" Catholics
column7: Jews
column8: Mormons and free Black churches are included.  This is interesting but the majority of America belong to four or five major churches where the crisis takes place.  Do we really care that the Mormons feel the failure to elect their leader President in 1856
column9: brought on the Civil War?  This information and justification of the idea consumes about 1% of the book's text.  A good point is the discussion of the Biblical justification of slavery and the response of the abolitionists.   This helps understand how in an anti-slavery society
column10: the abolitionists were still not accepted.  Their response was seen by the majority of Christians to reject the Bible's teachings.  This very important point if completely developed would have been a major contribution to the value of the book.  A real missed opportunity was to have a frank discussion of race in the years leading up to the war.  "The negro question" chapter never takes the "gloves off".  While suggested
column11: the pervasive racial discrimination of 19th century America gets glossed over.  Little is said about the idea of colonization or the laws preventing Negros from living where they wished.  The author deals with slavery but refuses to detail the racism that is its' foundation.  Doing so
column12: would have required a frank discussion of the plight of the Irish and Germans during this time.  Having just read Woodworth's excellent book on religion may color my view about this one.  The difference in approach
column13: historical information and readability is remarkable.

column3: so there is no element of surprise as the end develops.  2) SPOILER ALERT......................... ....................................... .......................................... The "dream"/"hallucination" (trying to not spoil too bad) scenes lose all creepiness because they are simply silly and stupid as opposed to frightening.  3) All the characters are so odd
column4: you really never care for George
column5: his wife
column6: his kids or anybody for that matter.  All in all it came across as a movie trying to be very "artsy-fartsy" and trying to create mystery by editing together random and erratic hallucinatory sequences simply for the sake of being confusing as opposed to being intriguing storytelling.  We were suckered in by the fact that one of the Producers of the TV show "24" was involved in this project. But that did not help this film at all.

column1: (Note: Rather than use the European name "Jesus"
column2: I will use Issa
column3: as he was called in India
column4: and Y'shua
column5: as he was called in Judea).  I was interested in this book because I was already inclined toward the ideas that Issa/Y'shua spent time in India and that he survived the crucifixion. Surprisingly
column6: I seem to be the only reviewer who welcomes the author's evidence of these points
column7: but is displeased with his slant.  Much of this book is about Islam
column8: which was founded 600+ years after the time of Issa/Y'shua
column9: and is therefore not relevant to the history being studied. The author's imposition of Islamic thought clouds the facts being presented.   The author attempts to examine Buddhism
column10: which Issa was said to have studied in India. He aligns Islam with "eastern religions" (without mentioning Hinduism) rather than Christianity. But Buddhists essentially strive for spiritual enlightenment
column11: while Christians and Muslims primarily worship God. Y'shua's closest associates in Judea were the Essene Nazirenes
column12: who were more enlightenment oriented than others in Judea at the time. A philosophic connection between Buddhism and the Nazirenes would have been a more relevant line of research.   There is a quote from "the last survivor of a long line of the hereditary attendants of the tomb"
column13: saying that the body in the tomb was that of Issa. Fine
column14: but why is that the only quote from that person? Who were these attendants? Were they descendants of Issa? Were they assigned by Issa to maintain the tomb per his instructions? And why did they leave it? It is mentioned a few times in this book that a mysterious aroma used to emanate from a hole at the tomb. When did it stop? Were the hereditary attendants asked about it? I wonder why this information wasn't included.   In another context
column15: there is mention of a blood line in India
column16: but the theory is that Issa/Y'shua was celibate throughout his youth
column17: and in his old age sired children with a servant. This is hard to believe. If he had taken an Indian wife on his first trip to India
column18: this would add another dimension to our understanding of why he might have returned to India later. Limited accounts of his first trip say he didn't
column19: but it might have been kept secret if she were of a lower caste (thus described as a servant). In this book
column20: the only question asked of a descendant is about written documentation of the marriage. I would like to have known about the beliefs and family lore of the descendants.  Issa's philosophy
column21: teachings
column22: and wishes regarding maintenance of his tomb
column23: are all brushed aside. But opinions of Muslims are discussed at length. It seems the purpose of this book is less to reveal the truth about Issa/Y'shua than to claim his legacy for Islam

column1: I was very excited to read this book as I have been looking for a biblically sound book I might be able to give away to friends to challenge their thinking about birth-control and children.  I am so sad to say that in the first two chapters there were three Scriptures which were so BADLY taken out of context
column2: I was forced to put the book down.  When I picked it up again and began to read through the entire book
column3: I found this unqualified biblical exegesis to be unfortunately common.    One example:  Mrs. Campbell uses Romans 7:4 as a support for God's purpose that marriage bring forth children.  Actually
column4: this verse speaks of our being united with CHRIST
column5: not a woman being united with a man in marriage.  Furthermore she interprets the idea of bearing fruit (in the same verse) as meaning we much bear children.  All throughout the NT you can see that bearing fruit is a spiritual metaphor for growing in Christlike-ness.    Another example: Mrs. Campbell uses Jer. 29 to support the same idea that God's intent for marriage is to produce children.  However
column6: the immediate context of this passage is Jeremiah contradicting the current false proohets who were saying that Israel should get ready to return to Jerusalem.  God is saying through Jeremiah that Israel should continue with life as usual (marrying
column7: having babies
column8: planting crops and harvesting and so on...) because they were going to remain in exile for the full 70 years.  I was disappointed with book because I was eager to hear a clear biblical presentation about why trusting God with your family size is biblical and God-honoring.  There is no such solid biblical teaching in these pages.  I don't think I would even recommend it for browsing.  "A Full Quiver" (Hess) gets much closer
column9: although this is not a whole-hearted endorsement of that book either.  May the Lord raise up someone who knows how to properly use the Scriptures in context to write on this topic

My report was done on Bradbury Speaks Too soon from the cave
column2: too far from the stars. At first this book looked very interesting. It said it would talk about space and how we would get to it and how far have we really come from earlier man. But I was proven wrong by the book. The book discusses Bradbury's life and how he met important people and interviews that went into the stuff described but it was really not at all about the future and space. That was the first sign of trouble. I then began to actually read the book. Oh boy was that hard. The context of the literature is so hard to understand. This was one of the most challenging books I have ever read. It wasn't hard language it was just the way he used it. I struggled all the way through this book just trying to understand what the heck he meant. When I finally did start too understand the book was still a huge bore.  All he would write about was himself and for all I could read about this book it didn't say anywhere that this was an autobiographical book. It says that the stories are written by students and journalists that have Bradbury. But they all sound like they are his words. Like that they are all in first person and they don't come from an interviewer's point of view. This really ticked me off. This book was down right hard. Now the stories themselves were really difficult. He wrote as if he had no personality. Giving only facts and making the stories dull and uninteresting. Half of them I couldn't even understand what they were about. They are so factual and have absolutely now pizzazz to them. This book gave me a sense of that no one knows what's going to happen to the human race. The book made me both sad and crazy. Crazy because he can't go directly to the point with out having a confusing remark that sent you off another road of thinking. So you would forget all about what you just read and have to start all over again. This is a book that requires too much attention from one person. All the stories talk about is how he met important people and how he likes the rain. Witch is really stupid. The book followed nothing from what you expect it to be. I would now read it if I were you. If you want a really good book about the future past and present don't look here. But if you are looking for a dull boring something you would read if you had to this would be the book for you. I lost interest in the book since the first page but I had to keep going because it was for school. Other wise I wouldn't bother with the book. I mean even the really weird Hitchcock films were better that this book. I would sit through one thousand Star Wars Episode I movies if I could not read this book again. I would not suggest this book for my life!

column1: Few leftist icons are looked upon more favorably than professor and activist Howard Zinn. Like many radical ideologues
column2: he is the darling of students
column3: the professorate
column4: and the glitterati. Indeed
column5: Hollywood star Matt Damon provided the narration for a hagiographic documentary about his life entitled
column6: Howard Zinn -You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train.  "You can't be neutral" is a reference to Zinn's belief that all history is skewed by the mind that conveys it
column7: and that the best historians must be "engaged" in political and societal matters. Therefore
column8: it is non-remarkable when their discussion of events always manages to be harmonious with their worldview. Such a post-modernist outlook is quite popular today
column9: but prevalence is not always an indication of value. Zinn informs viewers that no work is ever completely objective
column10: which then allows him (and other activists) to avoid using research and citations which do not substantiate their pre-determined suppositions.   That no historical account is ever 100 percent objective cannot be doubted
column11: but an automaton's level of clinical impartiality is neither possible nor expected. One commits a black-or-white fallacy by pretending that it is as nothing can ever be 100 percent objective or subjective. Good history doggedly attempts to be unbiased. When it abandons its detachment
column12: any amount of distortion becomes acceptable; history gets alchemized into propaganda. Zinn minimizes his own lack of scholarship in The Peoples' History of the United States by claiming that it was not written with an academic audience in mind.   As a man
column13: Zinn appears to be more celebrity than egghead. He isn't one to quibble over the nature of secondary or primary source materials
column14: he'd rather illustrate his points by quoting lyrics from a Woody Guthrie song. No doubt that the directors of this film ascribe to their subject's view of fairness as not one of the individuals interviewed uttered a single negative syllable about Zinn. Uniformly leftist luminaries like Noam Chomsky
column15: Alice Walker
column16: Marian Wright Edelman
column17: Daniel Ellsberg
column18: and Tom Hayden spent their segments exalting the importance of his impact upon society.   Their depiction of Zinn's personality was most revealing and in keeping with the tendencies of leftists in general. According to his friends and associates
column19: he possesses a "steely anger
column20: and an endless capacity for moral outrage" which is representative of the whole. Dr. John Ray's key psychological components of the leftist are discernible in Zinn as his need for fame
column21: praise
column22: power
column23: and attention are quite pronounced.   At one point
column24: Zinn's perceptions appear utterly astonishing. As a Jew in the Air Force who was sent to fight the Nazis during World War II
column25: he found himself in a position of
column26: what should have been
column27: absolute moral clarity. If ever a person was placed into a position where war was morally just
column28: this was it. However
column29: his reminiscences are confined to indignation over his unit's bombing an enclave of German soldiers. He lamented the action as the men in the French village
column30: "weren't doing anything to anybody"--except defending the boundaries of a genocide state.    Perhaps the best way to sum up Howard Zinn is through words he applied to Uncle Sam: "limited
column31: opinionated and with special interests."

column1: In book two of the Kathy Reichs series involving Temperance Brennan
column2: Tempe finds herself with dead bodies on two continents.  Upon examination
column3: she begins to find unusual similarities that link these deaths.  But how can the victims be so far apart and yet somehow be related?  What evil force is at work here and who can stop it?  And how is a nun's missing niece tied to the destruction?  To top it all off
column4: her eccentric sister from Texas has gone missing in Canada in her quest to "find herself."  Tempe must deal with whether some evil has touched her sister or whether this is just another installment of her sister's flaky personality.  The murders in this book follow Tempe from Montreal to the Carolinas in too far fetched a pattern.  Wherever this woman travels
column5: bodies pop up that no one but her can possibly deal with.  As an anthropologist it is logical that she would find herself dealing with skeletal remains
column6: but it is completely unbelievable to find that as she travels between her two homes that the bodies keep piling up and no one else is available to conduct the investigation.  Again Tempe is a heroine that is difficult to like.  When asked to assist with the deaths she whines internally about how she had other plans and really doesn't want to be bothered.  When she finally relents
column7: she has trouble associating the clues that she sees.  There are terrible lines illustrating this such as "that kindled something...in my memory cells
column8: but when I tried to bring it up the spark went out."  Another: "The mental itch was back.  What was it?  Why couldn't I bring it to the surface?"  Yet 100 pages later she is magically pulling it all together and making extrodinary leaps and bounds toward solving the crimes of the century.  This is my second attempt at Kathy Reichs.  I already own the next two books in the series
column9: so I will read them eventually
column10: but it seems as though this set of novels is a huge disappointment with ridiculous plots and an unlikable heroine

column1: "The Passing of The Great Race" was one of the racialist books written between 1855 and 1920 that would strongly influence the the National Socialist Party. The first was Gobineau's "The Inequality of The Human Races"
column2: the second was Houston Stewart Chamberlain's "The Foundations of The Nineteenth Century"
column3: the third was this one
column4: and the fourth was Lothrop Stoddard's "The Rising Tide of Color Against White World Supremacy". Grant was a lawyer and conservationist who was a firm beleiver in the Old Order
column5: free of Bolshevism and Socialism and centered around an Anglo-Saxon culture. Grant always tried to portray himself as more scientific than romantic racial theorists such as Chamberlain
column6: but his theories actually have little scientific basis. For example

column8: Alpine
column9: and Mediterranean Races is anchored only on the basis of Nordic Scnadinavians having blonde hair

column14: but there was never any record of Asiatic peoples reaching France or Germany

Grant considers the only pure Nordics to be people with blonde hair and blue eyes

column1: Robert Fried has designed a how-to book that articulates what passion in education is.  This topic has been lost in a black hole somewhere because  most often teachers are so busy that they do not have time to reflect on  what worked and what did not work in their lesson plans. 	The  Passionate Teacher demonstrates that we need to be more than just  passionate about our field of study - we need to build a "stance" about  students and learning.  Fried clearly illustrates that the quality of a  teacher's believing and behaving - what he calls "stance" - is what makes  passionate teaching possible.   Often times we find that the fear of  humiliation keeps students from sharing their most innovative
column2: controversial ideas
column3: resulting in a lack of energy and enthusiasm in the  classroom.  Throughout this book
column4: Fried offers real life personal stories  and ideas about how he and other teachers have put their passions to work.   After reading this book
column5: one can picture the effects of passion in the  classroom.   	Fried reminds us that what we think is important for  students to learn in order to be successful in life
column6: may not always be what  our students will feel they need.  He urges educators to build on knowledge  that students already have and to start bringing their interests into the  classroom. 	In the The Passionate Teacher
column7: Fried explores the question
column8: "Where do teachers hit the wall in their struggle to become or remain  enthusiastic about their profession?"  He offers strategies for getting out  of the "game" and onto something better.  To change the "game" teachers  need to start seriously listening to their students and find out what is  getting in the way of the kind of learning that they
column9: like all of us
column10: are  naturally supposed to seek out and respond to.    	Fried also stresses  the idea of having fun in the classroom.  Why wouldn't this make sense?   Most of a child's learning comes from play.  Teachers need to take a step  back and look at what they are doing - what they are teaching and ask  themselves what do they want their students to remember a year from now.   	 This is a book I am confident I will have by my side throughout my teaching  career. Fried's ideas are so inspiring. I have already begun implementing  his ideas and strategies into my planning.   I believe all teachers have  some element of passion for teaching
column11: even though it may be lost.  Fried  teaches us how to put this passion to work and how to bring passion back  into our classrooms

column1: The carver style of governance is a tad idealistic and perhaps overly optimistic.  I have read everything Dr Carver has written concerning this field and enjoy this material at an academic level.  But when it comes to  operationalizing this model in boardrooms I've seen it fail time and time  again.  Not to say that the model is flawed because in fact the model is  normative and conceptually complete.  However it doesn't capture that  element of reality from which
column2: in my experience
column3: the model requires -  practicality and real-world application.  Dr Carver's notion that Boards  can do without Finance and Audit Committees is very naive.  Most  consultants from the chartered accountant genre are saying the complete  opposite.  In fact most government policy initiatives are moving toward  more control of financial affairs of organizations for boards from charts  of accounts to fiscal policy.  So I don't think the elimination of Finance  and Audit Committees is realistic nor is it a terribly bright suggestion.   I guess my only crticism is that the carver model is far to idealistic and  philosophical for a practical application in the form Dr Carver suggests.   Sorry but a hybrid model of traditional Board governance and the carver  model may work given the commitment required from directors to  follow-though on everything suggested in that system of governance

column1: Much as I'm glad to have at least some of von Humboldt's very important travel writings availible
column2: this edition is sadly emasculated.    While it does include the initial Amazonian phase of Humboldt's South American expedition
column3: the narrative is cut short at mid-point
column4: von Humboldt's stay in Cuba.  It's inconceivable to me that the editor would have omitted all of the author's writing on his exploration of the Andes
column5: and in particular the volcanoes of South America.    Those excluded descriptions are not only fascinating to read today
column6: but were also what most inspired readers in von Humboldt's own day.  As a matter of fact
column7: von Humboldt's account of the Andes so inspired the 19th-century imagination
column8: that the era's greatest landscape painters
column9: such as Frederic Church
column10: actually travelled to South American specifically to witness and depict the vistas which von Humboldt had recorded in print.  The integral von Humboldt
column11: in contrast with the one presented here
column12: wanted not simply to view and record exotic cultures and climates
column13: but far beyond this to attempt as much as possible to experience the totality of the Cosmos in microcosmic form.  The closest von Humboldt came to this impossible experience was his rapid ascent of the large volcanoes of South America
column14: insofar as in this manner he could pass
column15: virtually
column16: through all the Earth's various climates in a single day--an astounding and Romantic feat completely unavailable to anyone using this edition as an introduction to von Humboldt.    But none of the above can be glimpsed even remotely by the reader equipt with only the Penguin edition.  Because of the premature truncation of the text
column17: one entirely loses sight of von Humboldt's overarching project
column18: which was not merely a geographical descripton of the Earth's surface
column19: but rather a geodetical construction of the World as an organic Unity.  Thus abbreviated
column20: von Humboldt appears scarcely different from his Enlightenment precursors; we lose all view of him as writer who has passed through defiles of Romanticism.  Not the real von Humboldt at all.    Rather than making one rash cut down the middle
column21: the editor would have served the reader much better by extracting key episodes from von Humboldt's entire journey.  As I said above
column22: something is generally better than nothing at all.  But in this particular case
column23: not much better

It's been quite some time since I read this book
column2: and my tastes in languages have changed quite a bit since then
column3: so it's possible that if I read this book today
column4: I would have a different impression. However
column5: I am doubtful that that would be the case
column6: and as it stands
column7: my memories of this book leave a bitter taste in my mouth.  The joke goes that "some programmers can write C/Fortran code in any language
column8:
and that is exactly the problem with this book. The compiler implemented within may compile correctly under javac, but it isn't implemented in a modular, object oriented way like one might expect when using such a language. Rather, the author seems to often use classes as little more than C structs, and methods as merely convenient ways of grouping together functions. I see now that the author also has a book on C compilers, and it wouldn't surprise me if the code herein was a direct port to Java, with as little redesign as possible.  I am certainly not an expert on compilers, and as I said, it's been quite some time since I read this book. The general information on compiling in this book might be useful, and I'll leave it to other people to make comments on that. However, if you are looking for a book that gives advice on what patterns work well when developing compilers, or what advantages an object oriented language might bring to the table in that arena, this is not the book you're looking for. This might teach you how to write a compiler that is, syntactically, Java, but it won't give you any insight on why you'd want to use Java over any other language

 An Autobiography of Jack Gantos told under the name of Joey Pigza. While Jack Gantos sits in his jail cell he tells you the story of how he got there. Young Jack wants to be a writer, but growing up in a poor family means that he doesn't have the money to go to school. So he goes to live with his grandparents in the Virgin Islands. Shortly discovering how much Jack drinks, they kick him out. 	From there, he goes to live with a family who have an extra room and he messes that up too when he gets sick all over their house. After going through that and a ghetto hotel, he goes home to St Croix to live with his parents and work with his dad. He makes minimum wage by making and shipping crates. When a gut named Hamilton comes in with blueprints for a special crate for smuggling hash he offers jack a job. Jack sees the opportunity to get rich quick and use it to go to college, he had no second thoughts. He ends up in a medium security prison for smuggling drugs to the US. 	I really enjoyed this book because I, myself have done wrong things to do good things. I've also thought about doing things to get money quick. It's easy to make bad decisions when things are hard in life. this is an awsome book for teenagers to read and i think everybody should read this

column1: I've never taken an economics class in my life.  I'd always heard that economists spoke a different language than everyone else
column2: and in some instances
column3: lived on a different planet than everyone else.  After reading the very enjoyable "Freakonomics
column4: I decided I might be wrong, because if Freakonomics" was an example of what Economics is all about
column5: then it was fascinating.  So I went in search of a book on Economics that would also be accessible to the layman
column6: and came across "Hidden Order
column7: which only reinforced my earlier stereotypes.  Despite a great opening chpater or two, I put the book down after 5 chapters, as each one became more incomprehensible than the last.  I have no doubt there is some very good information in this book.  Unfortunately, it's written in a mixture of English and Economics-ese" -- just when you think you're close to understanding what Friedman is trying to get across
column8: he throws in a chart and some terminology that makes everything incoherent.  On top of this
column9: many of the examples and explanations he uses make absolutely no sense...at least no sense to anyone who lives in the real world.   Perhaps this book would be useful to someone who has taken an Econ class or two
column10: but if you haven't
column11: you'll simply find this book frustrating.  Thank goodness I checked it out of library and didn't have to pay for it

column1: Back in November
column2: I started "The Diet Cure."  I was a little overweight
column3: had low energy and mood problems.  Thought eating healthy would help.  Oh man.  Increasing my protein intake from the little (or none) I ate to the whopping 20g a meal that she recommends (and cutting down drastically on carbs) brought on a state of ketosis that caused a constant ache in my kidneys.  On top of that
column4: my face started flushing beet red every couple of hours.  I was miserable and teary and almost passed out on the street. So I stopped the Diet Cure after four days.  Just FOUR DAYS of it and FOUR MONTHS LATER I am still struggling to deal with the mess it has caused in my body.  My doctor says it triggered hypoglycemia
column5: which I have to manage by eating six carefully controlled meals a day.  My kidneys seem to have bounced back
column6: but the mystery facial flush only stopped a week ago after I tried everything I knew to deal with it. I know that it's not Julia Ross's fault that I wasn't eating any protein to begin with
column7: but I do think her advice was highly irresponsible.  Sudden
column8: dramatic dietary changes can mess you up irreparably.  I have heard similar stories from a number of people now.  I wish I'd heard them before I read this book.  Sudden dietary changes can give you big
column9: nasty
column10: lifelong diseases like colitis or hypoglycemia
column11: just to name the ones I've personally heard about. What's sad is that the diet she recommends is actually pretty good for me.  If she had advised me to gradually ease on to it over a period of 12 months
column12: I'd be writing a very different review. So please please please
column13: if you're considering following this program
column14: make the changes gradually.  If you do it fast
column15: what happened to me may not happen to you - but why take the risk

column2: taken at face value
column3: can destroy the understanding of the period it sets out to explore.  A caution is not enough for this book.  Its immense learning on a small range of things - useful enough for the specialist - goes with the most spectacular ignorance of the wider area
column4: so that Gnosticism can be taken to embrace both Plotinus and Hermes Trismegistus
column5: in fact anything that is not properly Catholic. Hans Jonas' problem is not specialization; specialization is only his excuse for what is an unconscious but almost deliberate refusal to learn certain categories
column6: a refusal to challenge his own inadequate views on some matters
column7: his unthinkng adhesion to a way of thinking he learned early - or rather
column8: never learned at all
column9: but absorbed as attitudes from the surrounding environment - and never challenged.  In particular
column10: he assumes as obvious that heresy is inherently creative and orthodoxy inherently destructive (rather than the reverse)
column11: so that all the positive advances in religious history
column12: from mysticism to monasticism
column13: are to be ascribed not to the Christian Church but to his beloved Gnostic rebels.  I would guess that it is from this presumption
column14: a fundamental and basic superstition that dominates his entire outlook
column15: that he set out to study the ultimate in heresy
column16: Gnosticism
column17: in the first place.  He expected to find spiritual creativity and progress there
column18: and he found - or rather
column19: "found" - what he wanted.  It is not that specialization ruined him
column20: but that the already accomplished ruin of his mind governed his choice of specialization.  That this sort of presumption in favour of heresy should go with a Bultmannite background - which logically should have no particular reason to go hunting in this particular preserve - only goes to show that sooner or later all heresies meet; if not on logically defensible grounds
column21: at least on the common ground of the common hatred of orthodoxy.  And yet there is one last doom to which this sort of person is inevitably put: just as they think that they have taken the struggle against orthodoxy to its climax
column22: they suddenly find themselves outdated and almost reactionary - in this case
column23: by the rise of a new school of anti-orthodoxy associated with the name of Karen L. King
column24: who
column25: far from proclaiming the high merits and unique historical position of Gnosticism
column26: proclaim that no such thing as Gnosticism ever existed - it was all a wicked intellectual construction put on their enemies by the nasty
column27: colonialistic
column28: male-imperialistic Catholics
column29: which
column30: after two millennia of obscurity
column31: has finally been revealed by the lights of feminist
column32: deconstructionist
column33: non-judgemental theory!  Ain't life grand

Don't waste your money!

column1: This book is basically Marxist view of art
column2: and what art is intended to accomplish.  This isn't necessarily a bad thing!  It does help you to examine your assumptions and beliefs a bit
column3: and that's one of the things an education is supposed to do.  The book repeatedly hammers the idea that art serves the purposes of the ruling class.  This is beat upon to the point of tediousness.  There is also a chapter that can be summarized as "art serves the purposes of powerful men by trivializing women and encouraging them to think of themselves as an object d'art for the viewing pleasure of others.  Oddly enough
column4: the book didn't really return to this them in the final essay when it talked about the visual image in advertising.  That's an arena where visual imagery is used to play on the insecurities of everyone
column5: but especially women
column6: to convince them that they are flawed and need __(fill in the name of a product)____ to be happy and respected and glamorous. Speaking of which
column7: one of the more interesting points in the book (even though I believe it is flat wrong) is the discussion of the rise of "glamor" as a desirable trait.  I found the book interesting
column8: and it irritated me
column9: but only in a good way--By making me think about my views.  But it really is written from the perspectives of a trendy liberal from the early 1970s.  Instead of closing with a powerful message summarizing some important aspect of art that we have been taught
column10: the authors even use the final paragraph of the last essay to point out that capitalism exploits the masses and coerces them to ignore their own best interest(that's literally what it says!).  Probably worth reading
column11: but not a high priority.  The Penguin edition is compact and affordable
column12: but the B&W images are so small that much of the value of the work is lost--You can't see details of the art being reproduced

column3: the protagonist

column6: a repressed intellectualism
column7: is barely even mentioned.  Mattie Silver
column8: Ethan's object of desire
column9: is an underdeveloped character in the most extreme sense of the phrase. It is unclear what her motives and feelings are even by the end of the story. However

column11: she comes off at immature and thoughtless.  Zeena
column12: the supposed antagonist
column13: is actually the easiest character to feel for. But don't get me wrong
column14: she's unlikable just like the rest of the characters.  Overall
column15: I suggest you avoid this book if at all possible. It's a loppy book with no real purpose or message.
