column12: brassy
column13: boorish
column14: single mother of three young children
column15: with no marketable work skills
column16: a transparently opportunistic manner
column17: who dresses very much the same way as the prostitute character Roberts played in "Pretty Woman" (prior to Richard Gere's character taking her on the infamous Rodeo Drive shopping spree).  The movie's beginning finds Erin unemployed and pursuing a personal injury lawsuit in connection with an automobile accident; her lawsuit is lost
column18: primarily thanks to her own disastrous testimony (swearing
column19: cursing and shrieking from the witness stand) while being questioned by opposing counsel.   Unbelievably
column20: Erin parlays the failed lawsuit into a job at her attorney's (played by Albert Finney) firm
column21: mainly by pushing her way into the office and ensconcing herself at a desk.   Later
column22: while handling the paperwork for a run-of-the-mill
column23: pro bono
column24: real estate sale
column25: Erin discovers the file contains the seller's medical records
column26: that
column27: for reasons she (correctly) does not understand
column28: seem to be of particular interest to the buyer
column29: the mega utility company
column30: Pacific Gas and Electric.  Erin independently embarks on her own personal investigation of the case and discovers that PG&E had (for decades) negligently contaminated the ground water (surrounding one of their power plants in/near Hinkley
column31: CA on the edge of the Mojave Desert) with toxic
column32: hexavalent chromium.  This discovery leads to the queen mother of all class-action lawsuits (at least in terms of the award)
column33: in which hundreds of Hinkley residents sue PG&E (by and through the representation of Erin's boss) in a toxic tort action that eventually nets a 330 million dollar settlement for the plaintiffs.  Roberts gives a photogenic
column34: if not especially gifted
column35: performance in her role as Erin. The movie contains a plethora of flattering shots of Roberts (literally gushing out skin-tight
column36: low-cut
column37: bustier-inspired "work clothes" that would never be permissible attire for any employee of a law firm on this planet) as she engages in warm and fuzzy discourses with the unsuspecting and unsophisticated Hinkley residents. While there is much to be said for Erin's apparent drive and tenacity as she pursues the plaintiffs in the suit
column38: she is not an especially likeable character; rather
column39: she is rude
column40: verbally abusive and only conciliatory and kind when and if it serves her interests.  Albert Finney is considerably more appealing and believable as Ed Masry
column41: the aged and  weary attorney who is Erin's boss.  The bantering that occurs between the two is generally amusing; unfortunately thanks to the inept direction and camera work
column42: the focus for these scenes seems to be more on Roberts (strutting about in short leather skirts and noisy
column43: five-inched-heeled mules) than on the sometimes-interesting personality dynamics that seemingly exists between the two characters.  Aaron Eckhart plays the affable
column44: gentle biker and next-door-neighbor
column45: George
column46: who becomes Erin's boyfriend-by-convenience.  The "convenience" factor is totally one-sided and for Erin's benefit exclusively; she  unabashedly uses George for free
column47: live-in childcare
column48: thereby giving her the necessary freedom to assist Masry as they put together the historic case.  Erin eventually winds up receiving a staggering two million dollar "bonus" check  (from Masry) when the tort action case settles; contrastingly
column49: George gets a "thanks" for his nanny services from Erin and his walking papers.   The plaintiffs in the case are an assortment of simple individuals with unpretentious outlooks on life
column50: who have been dealt a dirty hand by the utility giant.  Though the Hinkley residents are sympathetically portrayed
column51: make no mistake-this movie is about Erin Brockovich (indeed
column52: I do not think there is a single scene in which the chacracter is not present) and less about the brave struggles with life-threatening
column53: generation-spanning illnesses that the real-life plaintiffs were forced to face
column54: due to the toxicity in their water source.  Erin Brockovich is presented to the viewing audience (in typical Hollywood fashion) as a sort of heroine; but in fairness it would seem more accurate to say that she was a woman who indiscriminately used people
column55: walked on others when necessary and seized opportunity after opportunity until she eventually struck it lucky and got rich.  Is the movie entertaining-absolutely.   Inspiring- not even slightly.

column1: In this work
column2: Boswell argues that rituals for the binding of two males (in Eastern Christendom) between the 12th and 16th centuries is evidence of the support for same-sex marriages in earlier Christianity. This is yet another example of a scholar misinterpreting historical facts in order to serve an agenda.  Robert L. Wilken
column3: Professor of the History of Christianity at the University of Virginia
column4: wrote an excellent critique of Boswell's work. The article is entitled "Procrustean marriage beds" and is found in Vol. 121 of Commonweal
column6: pp 24. It is also on the web (do a google/yahoo search).  Here's an excerpt: On an initial reading these rituals appear similar to marriage ceremonies. They refer to the joining of two people in life-long relationship
column7: they speak of a bond of peace and love and oneness of mind
column8: they include ritual actions that parallel those of marriage ceremonies. Yet there are certain features of the rituals that are unlike marriage ceremonies. For example
column9: the texts make it clear that the relation of the participants is spiritual not carnal ("by faith and spiritually")
column10: there is no mention of the marriage bed
column11: the term "marriage" is not used (as it is in marriage rites)
column12: the biblical readings are different from those used in marriage ceremonies
column13: several of the rites
column14: significantly
column15: indicate that the relationship is that of an "elder" to a "younger
column16: and the persons joined in the ceremonies are males.  Wilken then continues with specific examples. It turns out that, as Wilken states, What these rituals solemnize is not 'gay marriages' but a form of ritualized friendship between males that had been practiced in the Eastern Mediterranean since the time of Homer." And
column17: of course
column18: Wilken proceeds to support this and gives reason for why this was done. His article is an excellent read.  For those Christians who promote the affirmation of homosexual practice
column19: this book is too good to be true. Alas
column20: it turns out that such is the case

column1: I chose this book for a college writing class assignment. I had to read it
column2: then critically review it. I've always been an avid reader
column3: and no book has ever made me feel stupid

column5: sentences
column6: and formats he could think of. Some of the stories took me days to get through
column7: and I only finished them because I had to. Some were better than others; I sort of liked "Boys" and "Forecast From the Retail Desk"

column10: "Ineluctable Modality of the Vaginal" (16 pages - 1 sentence - give me a break)
column11: and the two "list" stories: "Wilkie Fahnstock: The Boxed Set" and "Surplus Value Books: Catalogue Number 13". None of the stories had any real character development
column12: and some had no recognizable plots. There are maybe people who will understand this stuff better than I
column13: but this is still not a book I would recommend to anyone I know. If you're someone looking for enjoyable short stories

column1: Sediment and metal particles settle in the bottom of your drain pan and these kits can't siphon all that out. I have to confess I didn't get very far with this one. If you have to read this for a course
column2: I'm very sorry.  I'm not an academic
column3: but I do I read a lot of philosophy. I'll put a lot of energy into a complex text
column4: but I prefer to invest it with works that will enlighten
column5: not confuse.   On the clarity-precision scale
column6: I would push Levinas right past "dense" or "challenging" and put it somewhere between "turgid" and "impenetrable." (His apologists decry the inability of human language to convey Levinas' sophisticated thoughts. Maybe so
column7: but perhaps the apology says more about his thoughts than it does about human language.)  In any case
column8: it will take you a long time to genuinely read this book. If you're looking for truth (as opposed to a passing grade in a required course)
column9: you would be better served by spending 3 hours contemplating and reasoning to your own working definition of the following words:  --- "totality" --- "infinity" --- "other"  Then spend 3 hours contemplating and reasoning to your own understanding of how the three are interrelated.  Then get a decent translation of Aristotle's Metaphysics. (I like the McKeon translation
column10: but there are certainly newer
column11: hipper ones.) Then read Aristotle instead of Levinas. If you find the idea of reading a Dead White Guy repugnant
column12: spend the time watching water move over rocks. Either choice will provide you more wisdom than you could get from a lifetime studying An Essay on Exteriority

column1: I must begin my review by stating that I am a reader of all memoirs because I find them to be healing for the soul. The best memoirs are honest accounts
column2: whether the truth is devastating
column3: beautiful or just plain boring.  I bought 'A Piece of Cake' because the rave reviews and because it was becoming available in paperback. After finishing 'A Piece of Cake'
column4: I must be honest that it is one of the worst memoirs I have ever had the misfortune of reading. The writing seemed to be done by a grade schooler: repetitive
column5: juvenile and inconsistent - but this is not the reason the book is so bad. 'A Piece of Cake' is not a good read because I just don't believe 90% of what Miss Brown wrote.  I believe bad things can happen to a child in foster care
column6: that kids in the ghetto get caught up in the gang lifestyle and addicts have a lot of interesting stories to tell. The reason I don't believe Miss Brown is that there is no honesty in her literary voice. Her stories are built from rusty crumbs and do not hold solid.  There are so many instances in the book that don't hold up to the light
column7: but the most glaring untruth seems to be that the state of California would award custody of Miss Brown and her brother to their biological father and at the same time pay state dollars to a foster parent for their care. This especially seems untrue since there were other blood relatives who wished to take on the responsibility of caring for Miss Brown and her brother without the state's money. Since the whole book is based on this foundation
column8: the whole story crumbles.  After reading 'A Piece of Cake'
column9: it is my feeling that Miss Brown was faced with many hardships in her young life and chose a road of self-destruction. She was able to climb out of the gutter and this is always a wonderful thing
column10: but it does not necessarily mean that one's story should be made into a book.  Cupcake Brown obviously has many devoted fans of her book and I'm in the minority with my criticism. However
column11: I stand by my review 100%.  Some memoirs that I highly recommend are:  'The Glass Castle: A Memoir' by Jeannette Walls 'Ava's Man' by Rick Bragg 'Angela's Ashes' by Frank McCourt 'Blackbird : A Childhood Lost and Found' by Jennifer Lauck 'Traveling Mercies: Some Thoughts on Faith' & 'Operating Instructions' by Anne Lamott (or anything else by Anne Lamott) 'Running with Scissors: A Memoir' by Augusten Burroughs 'Naked' by David Sedari

column1: These are the type of books and garbage that let an actual  abuser get away with harrassing an ex-spouse and using a child as a pawn.  Doesn't anyone realize that this gives guilty people a loophole to pass the blame for the degradation of a parent child- relationship to someone else.  If your child doesn't like you
column2: then you need to look inward at your own shortcomings and fix yourself
column3: not look outward for someone to blame
column4: just because admitting the truth is too difficult.  Maybe your child just doesn't like you...and maybe the child really has been abused. I've had about enough of all these fake syndromes.  I read this book and I am appalled.  No child who truly loves and admires a parent can be manipulated into "revisionist history" and being poisoned.  Society needs to give children more credit than that...and the authors of these "books" need to find something else to do.  Only a lemming would be so stupid as to follow this author's suggestion that parental alienation is possible simply by "telling" a child anything.  Children will continue to love and admire a parent who is worthy regardless of circumstances. If you've lost their love and affection you have only yourself to blame.  My ex tells my son terrible things about me all the time
column5: and my son simply comes home and tells me what is said.  He follows that up with "I love you" and "I know the things that are said aren't nice".  It has not damaged my relationship with my son whatsoever
column6: but my ex has lost the respect of this child.  Think about what is in this book
column7: and then put it down and run...never to follow this kind of bunk again

column4: and they use data sets to record the sites and sizes of them. It provides an overview of what the future holds for oil production

column1: Shekhar Kapur's vision of A.E.W. Mason's The Four Feathers is well done visually
column2: but unfortunately much of the original story is lost to create a more fast-paced and action-packed plot. While the basic story is kept
column3: many small details seem to have been needlessly changed. For those who don't know
column4: The Four Feathers is supposedly about Harry Feversham
column5: a man enlisted in the army. When Harry is informed he will be sent to war in the Sudan
column6: he hides this information and quietly resigns from the army to be with his fianc
column7: Ethne. However
column8: life with Ethne is soon changed when he receives three white feathers from his army colleagues. Explaining to Ethne what he has done and that the feathers are a symbol of cowardice do not help Harry; in fact
column9: she tears a feather out of her fan to make four feathers. Harry then sets out to regain the lost respect of his friends through helping them
column10: in an ultimate goal to regain the respect of Ethne.  For the most part
column11: only minor details are changed from the novel to the movie; for example
column12: the way that Harry's friend
column13: Jack Durrance goes blind
column14: or the fact that Harry disguised himself as a Greek
column15: not as an Arab. The change that seems most prominent
column16: however
column17: is the fact that in the film
column18: Jack Durrance knows of Harry's resignation from the beginning. This subverts the whole quest that Jack undertakes to find out the truth in the novel. In addition
column19: the entire `battle' between the warden of the House of Stone of Omdurman and Harry and Abou Fatma was created solely for action value in the film. However
column20: despite this addition of action
column21: the movie still seems to drag at points.  Films are almost never completely accurate when following a novel; that is why they are only based on them. However
column22: as I've said
column23: a lot of the changes made seem senseless. I would recommend this film to someone who has not read the book or who does not mind liberal film interpretations of novels
column24: if they have an hour or two to waste. Those looking for a movie to keep them on the edge of their seats would be advised to find something else.

column1: Given the book is from Kathleen Jamieson I was a tad dubious the book would offer objective information. column2: or at least express a more thorough examination of political issues than is possible in her tv clips. I could not have been more mistaken. The reviews on this page accurately describe most essays as dull
column3: which they are. Anyone who is even remotely in touch with news sources outside of the Today Show is aware of the "sound bite" culture we live in
column4: and the consistent disparity between public pronouncements of our elected officials and the telling details. Ho hum - we really don't need a dozen essays to tell us this. More telling would be a thorough examination of WHY this phenomenon persists
column5: which requires more analysis of the news media which drive our political culture. Face it
column6: most of what politicians do is performed with one finger in the wind
column7: and that wind is largely blown from the network news studios. If they approve
column8: then there is no problem; if they criticize and question
column9: then our friend the politician has a problem. Preening on tv is the coin of the real for most politicians today
column10: not the art of statecraft. The homogenous make-up of the news opinion leaders is proven left-leaning. Exhibit "A" is Walter Cronkite
column11: once the most "trusted man in America" and now an outspoken liberal
column12: who is also known for once saying in order to be a good journalist one HAD to be liberal. Have a look at the cumulative public and private pronouncements of Tom Brokaw
column13: Jane Pauley (married to Gary Trudeau)
column14: Dan Rather
column15: Judy Woodruff (married to the liberal Al Hunt)
column16: Peter Jennings
column17: Barbara Walters
column18: Diane Sawyer
column19: Connie Chung
column20: etc.
column21: etc.
column22: etc. They are all Democrat-friendly and critical of Republicans. When was the last time  you heard ANY network anchor express admiration for Ronald Reagan? Of course you have not
column23: because it hasn't happened. This is why the book is a yawner
column24: it is mostly liberal academics decrying the state of political discourse in this nation
column25: but they can't point the finger at the culprits of chronic misinformation because they are
column26: in fact
column27: their liberal brethren in the main-stream news media. Why
column28: I may ask
column29: is the nation over 2 years removed from economic recession
column30: yet nearly 50% of the country still believes we are in recession? Putting aside your feelings on the economy
column31: the empirical fact is we are NOT in recession. This is an indictment of the news media
column32: that the people are so terribly misinformed about something so important as the economic state of their country. They should be ashamed at their terrible reporting
column33: but dont' bet a lobster on it. They are certainly proud
column34: as they have somehow saddled a Republican president with the image of a bad economy in an election year. Clinton's economic numbers were not much better than Bush's
column35: yet the media consistently trumpeted his handling of the economy (which was in strong growth when he came into office
column36: and was in negative growth when he left). For a truly informative book on understanding the underpinnings of American political discourse
column37: ignore this book and pick up "Amusing Ourselves to Death" by Neil Postman. It is neither liberal nor conservative
column38: but the watershed work on how our basic cultural values limit what we are capable (collectively
column39: not individually) of understanding about politics and the nation in general. Good times come and go
column40: but stupid is forever. The title of Ms. Jamieon's book is as misleading as its contents
column41: and the perfect embodiment of the empty-headed academic pseudo-insights we'd all benefit by avoiding

column1: As a psychiatrist and person with mentally ill family members
column2: I can only bemoan all of the misinformation contained in this book. The truth is that many of the mentally ill in America do not get the treatment they need precisely because they believe the things said in this book
column3: on tv
column4: etc. As someone who has lived outside of the US and in the developing world
column5: I can tell you that their mental health treatment pales compared to what is available in the United States and is much more primitive and coercive. Although it is true that many psychiatric medications have serious side effects
column6: the consequences of living with symptoms of a serious mental illness can only convince you of how devastating that can be to both the ill person and his or her family. Furthermore
column7: as someone who is also experienced in administering ECT
column8: I can personally attest to the wonderful success rate of this treatment for persons with severe depression who have failed all alternatives and who would rather be dead than live out their lives. (And many
column9: unfortunately
column10: do decide on death as a last resort).  As far as lobotomies
column11: ice baths
column12: and forced stays in hospitals or other facilities
column13: these are things of the past in the United States. In fact
column14: one of the biggest problems I face in my practice is the extreme difficulty I have in placing someone in the hospital when they actually need a brief stay (typical stays are 5-7 days) because of a lack of psychiatric beds ( more than 90% of psychiatric beds were eliminated from American hospitals in the last 15 years as a cost-cutting measure). The other problems faced by modern psychiatry still includes stigmatisation of the mentally ill and then all the more mundane issues such as needs for help with housing
column15: employment
column16: and job development. But I bet you wouldn't find the author writing a book about that

column4: many of the stories and jokes come up flat.    This CD set is about 4 and a half hours long.  It was taken from several years of Anderson's live shows that eventually became the United States.  Each CD more or less covers a specific "tour".  Her back up band changes from CD to CD.  You can tell that as time goes on
column5: she gets more famous (and maybe has more money) she is able to add more to the shows (and her backup band gets bigger).  The sound quality is amazingly good.  It is sharp and crystal clear.  There is almost no audience noise
column6: which does help create a good atmosphere for her stories.  About 80% of the material is spoken word.  There is some music.  It is probably less than 45 minutes of the total 4 and a half hour production.  The recordings come from early in her career.  She later redid most of the best material and put in on other albums.    I would suggest getting her other CD's.  Or if you want to see her performance art work
column7: I would suggest searching out the Home Of the Brave VHS tape (I don't think it has been released on DVD).  Don't get the Home of the Brave CD

column6: who I'm sure will be hitting that "unhelpful" button

column8: they actually recorded the songs being played at 16 rpm or 78 rpm or whatever
column9: and expected people to both pay for and be entertained by it.  To me it's "experimentalism" at it's most pretentious and annoying (not to mention lazy-how about just writing some songs or something?)  The opening "Fur Immer" is actually a very nice encapsulation of the Krautrock sound
column10: as Neu! lays down some interesting synth and guitar textures over a driving beat.  Unfortunately
column11: the bass player's decision to play exactly one note throughout wears thin about halfway through the eleven minute running time.  "Lila Engel" is instructive as an influence on the post-rock movement.  Play this for any Mogwai fan and they'll instantly recognize the musical language.  Maybe I just picked the wrong introduction to the band.  Maybe Neu! and Neu 75 are better
column12: but after blowing sixteen bucks on this one I'm not sure I'm in a hurry to find out

Pages 1-40 disclose some background information relating to patents.  Here
column2: the author is plainly uncomfortable with the topic. Pages 41-107 describe various regulations relating to FDA submissions.  Here
column3: the writing is somewhat more assured.  On page 14
column4: the author states that "claims tend to get long winded because for some reason lost in the mists of time
column5: there can only be one sentence in each claim
column6: so that [sic] sentence sometimes gets very long."  This is false.  A basis for single sentence claims is the Patent Act of 1836
column7: but also in a publication from July 1836 called "Information to Persons Having Business to Transact at the Patent Office."    On page 15
column8: the author states that the Seaborg claim is a broad claim.  This is false.  The Seaborg claim is a species claim (a narrow claim).  The Seaborg claim is NOT a genus claim (genus claims are broad claims).    On page 15
column9: the author states that "the broadest patents have the shortest claims."  This is not really true.  The author forgets that certain extra words
column10: such as "comprising" or "or"
column11: are universally used to broaden claims.   Again
column12: the author might have described how "comprising language" is used to broaden claims.  The author also might have explained how "or language" is used to broaden claims.   But nothing is said about these techniques for broadening claims.  Note also that what can be broad is a CLAIM in a patent
column13: not the patent itself.  From the writing
column14: the reader might infer that the SPECIFICATION determines whether a patent's coverage is broad or narrow.  But this is not the case.  An author writing for a novice audience should not be using careless phraseology in referring to established
column15: clearly defined concepts.  On page 16
column16: the author tries to describe the Doctrine of Inherency
column17: giving the example of a mechanism of action of a drug.  This is a confusing example
column18: because there are really two issues going on in this example: (1) Inherency; and (2) Failure to satisfy the utility requirement (35 USC 101).  This is also a bad example because often
column19: when faced with a discovery relating only to mechanisms
column20: the patent attorney might draft a claim reading
column21: "A method to detect this mechanism" or "A method to stimulate this mechanism."  For the claim given by the author
column22: when written by an attorney to read "A method to detect this mechanism" or "A method to stimulate this mechanism
column23: only utility is an issue (inherency would no longer be an issue).  The author should have used the much better example found in a case from the Federal Circuit, In re Cruciferous Sprouts.  On pages 18-19, the author attempts to explain novelty, utility, and non-obviousness.  However, the author only mentions the statute 35 USC 103, and fails to mention 35 USC 102 (novelty) or 35 USC 101 (utility).  At this point, it is becoming clear that the book" is unusually disorganized and inaccurate.  On page 23
column24: the author states that "A patent is a sword
column25: not a shield. . ."  This is false.  As soon as a patent is filed
column26: it becomes a powerful shield
column27: as it can become prior art under 35 USC 102(e)
column28: preventing the allowance of U.S. patents
column29: e.g.
column30: of competitors.  Morever
column31: as soon as a patent application is published
column32: it also becomes a shield
column33: preventing the allowance European patents
column34: e.g.
column35: of a competitor.   On page 28
column36: the author tries to explain the "Function
column37: Way
column38: Result" test.  But what a mess the author has made.  The author writes
column39: ". . . it might infringe under the doctrine of equivalents because your gizmo has an element that performs a similar function by similar means in a similar way . . ."  What happened to "Result"?   Where is "Result"?  Where?  The author is further confused here
column40: because he uses the term "means."  In patent law
column41: the term "means" is used to invoke 35 USC 112
column42: paragraph six.  The term "means" should not be used when initiating an explanation of the Doctine of Equivalents.  Another mess.   On page 31
column43: the author writes
column44: "This is called prosecution history estoppel if you really wanted to know."  This type of comment is excessively informal
column45: and is not appropriate for a "book" on patent law.  On page 89
column46: the author states that "The FDA recently approved a combination of two well-known cholesterol lowering statins giving new life to Merck's Zocor by combining it with a newer statin sold by Schering-Plough."  This is false.   The compound of Schering-Plough is Zetia.  But Zetia (Ezetimibe) is not a statin.  This "book" contains only about 30
column47: 000 words.  This is the length of a typical law review article.  At $25.00
column48: this tiny "book" is no bargain.  The production could be better.  While the quality of the glossy cover is excellent
column49: the ink in my copy of the book is smeared on pages 34
column53: and 108.  Citations for cases
column54: and the names of cases
column55: are missing (pages 51
column58: 74).   This "book" contains way too many errors in its attempts to describe various issues in patent law.  For this reason

column1: I was livid at the author's underestimation of the intelligence of the American consumer and investor.  With his ludicrous assertion that the US and the world economy and the value of currency should be limited by the arbitrary supply of a yellow metal is ridiculous and has been pilloried for more than a half century by actual economists.  His arguments to support his conclusions are so fraught with logical fallacies
column2: any senior high school debator could rip it apart.  His fundamental lack of understanding of debt-backed securities is frightening as is his assertion that the US Government controls the money supply and the whimsical printing thereof.  For someone who lambastes with such slavering scorn
column3: the Federal Reserve Bank of the US
column4: I'm surprised he hasn't actually realized that the Federal Reserve Act of 1913 privatized monetary policy decisions in the US to prevent the federal government's capricious issuing of currency.  In addition
column5: if you're going to take on John Maynard Keynes and Alan Greenspan
column6: it would help to have a solid litany of proof
column7: rather than scattered and fragmented anecdotal evidence that spans perhaps 6 fiscal quarters at best.  Also
column8: when explaining the beginning and end of trends
column9: especially referring to the recent rise in gold prices
column10: cite actual data and genuine trends.  Any novice at Excel could plot the points you gave and realize that the trend started well before the 2001 recession. Throwing up a graph and misrepresenting its data further impugns the author's credibility and his "agenda."  Furthermore
column11: Mr. Wiggin
column12: as  a follower and commentator on the currency markets
column13: the dollar is down only against the euro--hardly a "demise."  All other currencies in the world
column14: peg themselves to the dollar because of the US's robust economy.  Eastern European and other black markets deal in dollars.  Perhaps you should take Macroeconomics 101 again and refresh your memory on the concept of debt-backed securities
column15: get a tutor to explain Keynes and write something that will do more than foment hysteria and promulgate misinformation and wild unsubstantiated conclusions.  And--return America to an beleaguered economy manufacturing expensive goods with that no one else wants to buy (think GM and its overwrought pension fund)--what are you thinking?  It would be nice to see a relevant observation with a logically sound conculsion.  Wiggin completely disregards the (Growing) portion of US GDP that is a direct result of services and entertainment and bemoans--in Jeremiah fashion--that doom is imminent because manufacturing's share of the GDP is declining.  His right-wing
column16: Bo-Gritz-for-president
column17: unsubstantiated diatribe may be gospel at a Libertarian mass meeting
column18: but his economic sturm-und-drang just doesn't pass academic or serious financial scrutiny.  While Americans are heavy spenders and should save more
column19: it's a perilous leap in logic to assume that the economy itself on the verge of collapse. Perhaps Wiggin should consult Moody's and Standard and Poors for a primer on the term "creditworthiness." I'm far more open to a study of the legitimate problems with the US economy--inflation
column20: the transfer of wealth from manufacturing to services
column21: or even the disappearance of the middle class.    All in all
column22: Wiggin refuses to acknowledge the single
column23: saving grace of a falling dollar--American goods and services cost less abroad--and more people consume what we have to offer.  An abysmal disappointment. Nothing more than a peurile rant from a two-bit charlatan.

It is typical of our marginally educated educators in this country to bungle their research. Carnoy's book is an example. They make absolute comparisions of student proficiencies after controlling for the some of the demographic and socio-economic effects but in so doing they leave out the most important factor of all: How did the students compare with their regular public school cohorts when they entered charter schools? Perhaps lost to these ed-researchers is the fact that charter schools attract low performers compared to the public school alternatives. The real measure of a quality school is not children's absolute performance
column2: but how much do they improve year over year. On that measure
column3: charter schools are signficantly superior to their regular public school counterparts.

column7: where her previous employer seeks her assistance in unwraveling the mysterious death of a young girl. column1: Have you heard?  Many Christians are seeking authentic Christian church life.  And they are leaving the institutional church (i.e. the religious buildings
column2: empty pagan rituals
column3: professional staff members
column4: etc.) to experience it!    This I applaud.  Many Christians would do well to read "Pagan Christianity" by Frank Viola.  The institutional church is not the model given to us by the apostles.  And please know... I grew up a Southern Baptist and was on the ministerial staff for 6 years.  This conclusion was not all that easy to embrace.  However
column5: I did discover it to be true.  Most truth loving people recognize the institutional church doesn't bring the results we see in the book of Acts. (e.g. read "Church Planting Movements" by David Garrison
column6: published by the International Mission Board)  Yet
column7: many are not willing to leave the comfortable confines of the man-centered institution to discover real ekklesia.  So... why did I rate this book so poorly if I am a part of a "house church" myself?  Because this book dishes out church in homes like it was fast-food!  Tony and Felicity Dale seem like wonderful people who have seen some great things happen in homes
column8: but it would seem their method of starting churches is not founded in the N.T.  First
column9: they use a proof-text (Matt.18:20) to establish the existence of a church.  A true church is a group of believers in a particular locality who have joined together in community for the purpose of gathering around Jesus Christ. (e.g. read "The Normal Christian Church Life")  A church is not just getting a couple of Christians together and doing a bible study or singing some songs. This idea is a really popular strand of "house church" that has many rushing out prematurely to do this.  These people have no real solid foundation and knowledge of the roles and workings of an apostle(church planter)
column10: prophet
column11: pastor/teacher
column12: etc.  In chapter 10 "IT'S OK TO START A CHURCH
column13: the Dales encourage you to nonchalantly go out and find someone who will allow Christians to meet in their home and walla!  You will have a house church".  Question: is this the model in Acts?  Go read it.  The Dales even admit from their experience that the life of many a "house church" does not last very long.  Why?? I believe it is because "Simply Church" is so simple it is not biblical.  If you believe that the church gathering in homes apart from the religious systems of man is what Christ and the apostles intended
column14: then you must believe there is an order to things.  (e.g. Eph. 4:11)    However
column15: if you believe church is a "cell group" or some other kind of alternative fellowship to the insitutional church... I imagine you can do whatever you want.  And many do.  Unfortunately
column16: these "house churches" usually do not last.  Why would you want to trade one wrong practice (the institutional church) for another (house church as alternative)?  It is not an alternative.  It is the model given by the apostles to the community of saints.  We must be careful we do not trade one man-centered institution that meets in a building for another man-centered instituion that meets in a home!  Remember-- Real Christian church life comes by gathering around Jesus Christ in the order of the New Testament.  T. Austin Sparks puts it this way
column17: "The church is measured by Christ: more Christ
column18: more church; less Christ
column19: less church."  The simplicity is found in gathering around Christ with a New Testament understanding of who we are and how we are to function within a local community of believers.  A biblical "New Testament" church comes about by a group of believers gathering around Christ the Head of the body.    The journey that you embark on in a true church... I believe can be represented in a picture.  It is a picture of believers hand-in-hand circled around the King of Kings and the Lord of Lords.  This community is singing
column20: encouraging
column21: rebuking
column22: correcting
column23: and edifying for the worship of the one in the center:  Jesus Christ
column24: the lamb who was slain!  Don't get hung up on mimicking the "first-century style" of church... be consumed with Christ!  Place him in the center.  In time... you will discover your church life is authentic.  I highly recommend you read the writings of Frank Viola if you are interested in gathering around Jesus and experiencing the freedom of the first-century church.  His book set is very helpful for those who seek to model Christianity in Acts.  He references his claims to Scripture.  Frank Viola's set: 1. "Rethinking the Wineskin: The Practice of the N.T. Church" 2. "Who is Your Covering: A Fresh Look at Leadership
column25: Authority
column26: & Accountabiltiy" 3. "Pagan Christianity: The Origins of Our Modern Church Practices" 4. "SO YOU WANT TO START A HOUSE CHURCH?: First-Century Styled Church Planting For Today" 5. column1: The Influetials is either just a big statistical blob or I missed something.  Keller et al start out by describing the influential as someone who other people in the community kind of look toward.  They are very socially connected and respected.  There is no doubt in my mind that the proposition that one in ten people has a huge influence on how the other nine think
column2: however instead of exploring the social patterns Keller et al try to define that person whom they call an "Influential"  They begin by saying in the first chapter that statistics can't pinpoint an influential and then spend most of the book tossing statistics on influentials at the reader - lots of tables that don't tell me anything.  One thing that I found interesting were the case studies scattered through the book.  Basically these were mini-biographies of influentials slanted more towards what they were up to at the moment.  Even these weren't all that helpful.  I recommend skipping The Influentials.  The title is really good but the book doesn't focus or do much to back it up.  Actually things just get muddled.  The Tipping Point by Malcome Gladwell has a good bit of discussion about who influences opinions and how.  Check that out instead

column1: . While the author attempts to appear even-handed by emphasizing her efforts in analyzing what she terms as "the Turkish view
column2: it is crystal clear she did not approach the matter with a scholarly perspective. Housepian Dobkin has no purpose other than demonstrating that the Turks were guilty.   It's amusing the way she tries to play innocent by writing that she was puzzled" that "a few" critics had found her book "highly charged" or "subjective." (When Dobkin cherishes fiercely anti-Turkish sources such as Dadrian and Hovannisian
column3: how in the world could she possibly be objective?)  For example: she herself writes
column4: "Mesopotamia's oil-rich lands were all this time under British military occupation." That explains it all; the British had laid claims to these oil-rich lands via secret treaties during the war. Oil was Britain's war booty all along. So Dobkin's attempts to make it seem like the Allies were being nice to the Turks for reasons of oil
column5: when the Turks no longer had control of these lands
column6: are very hollow.  An American who had changed his mind over Turkish excesses pointed out that to force foreign powers to control the treatment of minorities in Turkey would be "similar to foreign powers having insisted after our revolution on inserting a clause to the effect that we protect the American Indians
column7: an argument that Dobkin finds not only strained but absent-minded." Far from it; outside forces have no business in dictating the affairs of a sovereign nation
column8: yet Dobkin expects that Turkey should strangely be exempt from this rule.   She also complains about "the missionaries who had discredited their own eyewitness testimonies
column9: and others like Arnold Toynbee who had done an about-face from their former propagandistic views. Dobkin does not even consider the possibility that the former tellings of these partisans could have been false. (Toynbee was part of the British war propaganda division, for example.)  The author had already made up her mind on the guilt of her accused, and was strictly interested in finding sources to prove her case. A historian who wishes to arrive at real truth needs to consider all the sources. But as even one of her fans here pointed out, Housepian Dobkin is no historian. (Llacko, July 25, 2000) Dobkin made her case by referring to, as Llacko put it, first hand quotes
column10: at length
column11: from people who were actually there."  Yet there were people who were actually there with no reason to defend the Turks
column12: whose first hand quotes Dobkin purposely left out or de-emphasized. This was highly unconscientious of her. Her purpose is the same as some of the equally questionable reviewers here
column13: who seem to have no use for the truth. They have their prejudices
column14: and all they desire is to perpetuate their agenda. One can see this from the way in which they uniformly pile on the negative ratings on reviews that go against their ingrained beliefs.  One reviewer (Omer "aok34
column15: Aug. 1, 2005) who provided a taste of what these other parties had to say offered arguments that are are hard to dispute. The city's fire chief, a foreigner (Paul Grescovich) who was in the best position to know the goings on knew that the Armenians and Greeks were behind the fire. Why would Dobkin treat this as though it meant nothing? (She only referred to this testimony in her bibliography.) Grescovich had no reason to defend the Turks.   Then there is the American special representative to the Near East Relief, an organization meant to help the Armenians, and not known for its friendliness to the Turks. Mark Prentiss was there, and he was spectacularly honest in his reporting. Prentiss had no reason to love the Turks; he was strictly and only interested in reporting the truth.   At this writing, reviewer Omer only has 3 of 14 stars. It must be asked of the people who went out of their way to give a negative rating, why would they wish to perpetuate a falsehood in the face of irrefutable truth?  Omer asks why would a nation burn down its own city, especially when the rest of the nation lay in ruins. Indeed, why would they? Think about the logic: If the Greeks displayed a record of leaving a scorched earth policy during their retreat, how could these reviewers not bother to consider the actual incentive the Greeks had and constantly demonstrated, aided by the Armenians of the city? (The Greek priest Chrysostomos was overheard instructing his flock that it was their religious duty to set the city on fire. He was among the casualties, and as Dobkin footnoted, a French admiral felt the priest deserved his fate. Dobkin referred to the priest's individual death as a massacre
column16: by the way.)  As for the worth of the firsthand testimony Dobkin provides, an article written by Prentiss for the Atlantic Monthly in Jan. 1924 gives us deep understanding. The foreigners were so inundated by evil Turk" propaganda - not unlike many of the reviewers here
column17: it seems - that they actually claimed to have witnessed atrocity events that never took place. Repeat: they didn't purposely lie; they were actually imagining things. Prentiss wrote that he must have encountered a hundred such made up tales:  "It was too much for a good many men - and not weaklings by any means. They were like children
column18: who fail to distinguish between what they imagine or expect and what they really see. It is possible for an idea lo be so vividly present to the mind that it passes for fact on that ground alone."  And let's not forget there was no shortage of bigots who hated the Turks on account of their race and religion. The U.S. consul at Smyrna
column19: George Horton represented a fine example. He would actually go on to pen a hateful book called "The Blight of Asia." In his opinion
column20: the entire Turkish race was a "blight." Yet this racist is one of Dobkin's most beloved "eyewitnesses." (Diplomats generally did not check matters out firsthand
column21: relying instead upon what others had told them.)  When I look at some of the reviewers here
column22: I see the same kind of blind prejudice. Dianne Foster
column23: for example
column24: tries to come off as impartial at the start of her June 12
column25: 2002 review. And then she goes off to make unthinking propagandistic claims like 2 million Christians fleeing after Smyrna [is she referring to the resulting post war population exchange between Greece and Turkey as "fleeing"?]
column26: gives a glowing nod to the propagandistic film "Ararat
column27: and then admits her genocide sensitivities (with Smyrna making Kosovo look like a picnic")
column28: allowing her to easily buy into the claims of what Foster insists is a "scholarly" work. She actually believes there are over 200

column37: for a total of 250

The reason why "neutrals" like Foster can accept the claims of horrible propaganda is because they have a built-in disposition to believe the worst of the Turks... as a result of the continual bombardment of hatred from certain ethnic groups who make it their business to perpetuate this hatred. I am [...] the unit because it will not run a slideshow from a media card. 16 Mb of internal memory for a slideshow is just not enough! Read on!  If you call they will tell you that the slideshow from cards is not possible because on Page 13 refers to excluding pictures from the slideshow on only on internal memory. This is not a definitive statement that slideshow is not possible from a card only that excluding individual pictures from a card is not possible. (because the unit is not capable of writing to a media card.)   Looking further on p13 it states: "Choosing slideshow frequency Note: This function applies to photos stored on all media." Page 27 in FAQ states: "2) Q: Can I switch between different slideshows photos by using different memory cards? A: Yes. When you connect your memory card to PhotoFrame(tm)
column2: it will slideshow photos stored on that specific card." Finally
column3: the Quick start guide FAQ states: "Q Can I switch between different slideshow photos by using different memory cards? A Yes
column4: Digital Photo frame will slideshow photos stored in the card or camera currently connected."   Clearly the three references I provide indicate that the DPF can operate slideshows from a media card. IN REALITY SLIDESHOWS FROM MEDIA CARDS DOES NOT WORK. Philips how about a firmware upgrade?  I bought this thing to allow my mother who is not computer savvy and lives far away to look at family pictures. I was planning on sending preloaded cards to her. All she would have to do is insert the card and turn it on. (Mom is 75 and this is as technical as she gets..). Do not buy this DPF for older
column5: none computer savvy people. Since media card can not be used
column6: you have to use the internal memory for slideshows. The internal 16Mb memory can hold about 70 pictures - that's it. It is also unclear the maximum size a file can be. I believe the internal memory converts the file to a DPF friendly format and renames the file when copying from a media card. (How is Mom going to tell me which picture to print if the name changed?) Why have media card slots if they are useless? Internal memory is way too small! DO NOT BUY and save yourself the hassle.

column1: Every Christmas since I was 11 I have gotten this book as a gift. column1: This has to be the most boring book I have ever read. Well
column2: I haven't quite finished it yet as it's taking forever to push my way through it. And I'm sure that more boring books exist
column3: I just haven't read them.    I wanted to learn about KKR and LBOs - particularly as a division of KKR recently bought one of the vendors supplying my own employer. I was hoping for the big picture of what took place as well as some entertaining anecdotes. But this book consists largely of page after page of uninteresting minutiae of conversations between the various parties involved. There really is no need for such detail and a little bit of editing could have halved the size of the book without losing any essential information. And a bit of theoretical discussion would have been far more valuable than some of the biographical material. It felt a bit like watching someone else's home video. It probably means a lot to the people involved
column4: especially as they'll get the in jokes and quirks of the participants
column5: but it's painfully boring for strangers forced to watch it out of politeness.  I'm sure that much of the conversation is fiction anyway. People don't reliably remember this level of detail of converstaions over a period of years. What are remembered are broad brushstrokes - and this is what the author should have written.  There are occasional moments of entertainment - like Ted Forstmann obsessing about the evils of junk bonds. But most of the characters seem quite flat and uninteresting.   The fact is: I wanted some of this information in this book. As it provided some of this
column6: albeit with a lot of suffering on my part
column7: I'll give it two stars.  Update: Well I did finish this book eventually. My final opinion is much the same

column1: Unlike the rest of the Rich Dad books that I've read -- which were for the most part fantastic -- this book was terrible.  Michael Lechter may indeed be a very bright guy and a star in his field
column2: but he is an absolutely horrendous writer.  The intro by Robert Kiyosaki was the only really enjoyable part to the book.  Lechter immediately jumped into complex explanations of the various types of IP protection available without really clarifying anything for the lay person like me.  And no real life examples of anything -- just references to a couple hypothetical "horror stories" that he relays at the beginning of the book.  The only reason I gave this book 2 stars and not 1 is because at the very least I was able to get some basic definitions of IP terms down.  But I guess I could've gotten that from a dictionary too

column1: The best way to destroy sales is for the "author" to blast portions of the book.  In the follow-up to the commercially successful Catch This!

The line of children's books slated for release may be the venue for Owens to make a positive and lasting impression with fans.

column5: and the other half is Howlin' Wolf.  This is not a collaboration either.  This is SOME of the material taken from Muddy's highly acclaimed Fathers and Sons CD and SOME of the material taken from Wolf's London Sessions and basically glued together into one incomplete disc.  If you think you want a *sample* of either man's style
column6: this is probably a bad place to start because it only represents Muddy late in his career doing electrical blues and Wolf in a once-in-a-lifetime collaboration with the British rockers in London. column7: but they are not by any means a true representation of the bluesman that Wolf was.  As for Muddy
column8: you'd do much better just getting his Fathers and Sons CD.  Save your money here

column1: I bought this product after having taken Diet Fuel w/ ephedra several years ago. I needed energy this time and to lose a few extra baby pounds.  Within minutes of taking my FIRST and ONLY pill I had a horrible reaction.  I broke out in WELTS within 10 minutes all over my body. I was shaky and sick to my stomach.  I drank 5 glasses of milk to neutralize it and finally started to feel better. I thought I was going to die.  My only thought was there was no way losing weight was worth never seeing my kids again. After about 2 hours the welts disappeared but I felt horrible for the rest of the day.  Obviously there is something in it that doesn't get along with my body but after that reaction I had I have decided that no diet pill is worth the chance of what can happen to you.
After hearing and reading a number of astonishing things about this book
column2: I had to give it a read.  What I found was not exactly what I expected.  While some sources have described the Dru character as a "sinister dictator"
column3: the truth is not quite so interesting.  The book itself is nowhere near as interesting.  Upon opening the book to the table of contents
column4: one can't help but take notice of the number of chapters in this book.  There are 53 chapters in just 173 pages!  For those of you who don't have a math minor
column5: that's a little over 3 pages per chapter.  And for some reason
column6: many of the chapters are explicit continuations of the chapter before.  What was the point of this?  Why not keep the two chapters a single chapter?   Needless to say
column7: the writing here is atrocious.  The plot is paper-thin
column8: the characters don't develop one iota
column9: and a romance sub-plot rears its ugly head on the last two pages of the book!  How was this book published?  Why was it put into print?  Therein lies the intrigue.  While it was anonymously written at the time
column10: it is today well-known that the author of this book was Colonel Edward Mandell House (he gives a little hint in the text when two characters meet at Mandell House [yeesh!])
column11: who was the virtual co-president of the United States with Woodrow Wilson.  Wilson admitted time and again that House was his "alter ego"
column12: even to the point that House was given accomodations in the White House.  Why is all this important?  Philip Dru leads a revolution against the United States government.  Not a bad thing in and of itself
column13: if the reasons had been more compelling.  What happens in the aftermath
column14: however
column15: brings shudders to students of history.  Philip Dru becomes dictator of the United States
column16: without too much reservation.  He tosses out the national constitution
column17: as well as the state constitutions
column18: and has them rewritten.  He institutes a graduated income tax (which did not exist at that time in the U.S. because it was ruled unconstitutional;  however
column19: with the "ratification" of the 16th amendment just a year or two after the publication of this book
column20: we got one for the first time and have lived under it ever since)
column21: forces popular election of senators
column22: nationalizes industry
column23: and reorganizes the entire government at his whim.  And Dru is definitely portrayed as the friendly protagonist.  If the First Lady were to write a book calling for revolution
column24: abolition of the constitution
column25: and a unitary dictator
column26: would we worry?  I sure hope so.    But more worrisome is the fact that all of these thing eventually did come to pass in this country.  (Sure
column27: the constitution wasn't abolished and rewritten.  However
column28: the New Deal Supremee Court made rulings that effectively gave Congress carte-blanche to pass ANY law it felt like
column29: even those that explicitly violate the constitution [see USA PATRIOT Act]).  Was House prescient?  Did he simply see the tides of popular opinion swarming over the masses?  Or was he simply one of the many manipulating the domestic policy of our republic behind the scenes?  The structure and execution of this book are amateurish at best
column30: more likened to the writing of a 10th grader than any kind of real author.  Perhaps that is the point.  This book was clearly aimed at the unwashed masses.  Every piece of dialog in this book espouses the benefits of socialism and evil of capitalism.  But this effort is so transparent that it leaves us with nothing of any literary merit
column31: and in its place only political ramblings of a clear Fabian socialist.  These ramblings
column32: of course
column33: entail bringing up relevant issues and injustices (female suffrage
column34: corporate exploitation) and packaging them with solutions that involve only the addition and centralization of power in the federal government.  While those who educate themselves will see this work for what it is
column35: the many people who read this book (not today
column36: since people don't read
column37: but back then there were probably more than a few) would end up buying into bad solutions for exaggerated problems.  There is absolutely no reason to buy this book.  The price simply doesn't justify it.  A reader will gain no enjoyment from it.  This book only redeems itself in its historical context:  it was written by a man who pushed Woodrow Wilson to sign the Federal Reserve Act
column38: which destroyed our economy and continues to devalue our money to this day;  to lead us into World War I
column39: despite his campaign promises not to (the Lusitania was carrying English munitions and was a valid military target); and to attempt to sacrifice the sovereignty of our nation to a world governing body in the League of Nations
column40: which our Congress rightly rejected

column10: the ones who can be creative are a limited number. They help and enlighten us all. Can a teacher show a child that he or she really doesn't understand what he claims to "know"? Of course. Children are malleable. Even adults can be persuaded to revise their thinking by a sufficiently persuasive speaker even if what that speaker proposes is false. We've seen it time and time again. He's riding that old hobby horse that rote learning is destroying society. It's not. It's reformers like Prof. Gardner that are driving sincere educators to despair as they drive more and more dictators of our schools to believe that the education we are giving and have been giving is inadequate through and through

column6: alienating them from the world of face-to-face interaction; this happens in the case of a few troubled people
column7: but most people use the internet to enhance their already existing off-line relationships. The rest of the book basically argues that the network format of the internet is reshaping the rest of society in its image
column8: with everything from big business to governments to social movements adopting a network form in response to the rise of this new technology. This is
column9: frankly
column10: ludicrous reductionism. It doesn't even stand up to a simple test of chronology--a lot of the developments that Castells argues are driven by the internet predate the explosion of ist usage in the mid-1990s. As Castells himself admits
column11: businesses were already taking on more of a network form before the internet appeared big time on the scene
column12: and social movement scholars have shown the same is true of transnational social movements. On top of this
column13: Castells shows an effusive enthusiasm for all things networked
column14: whether they be transnational corporations or the transnational social movements that oppose these same corporations. I'm really at a loss to understand how one can enthuse about both of these opposed phenomena. Castells does see some of the problems with the new network society--loss of job security and the digital divide
column15: for instance--but he tends to downplay these. And his solution to these problems tends to come down to more of the same--more internet access
column16: more network social organization. Talk about a narrow vision

column1: Given that Professor Dahl has written numerous books on democracy and is considered an expert in the field

column3: preconditions
column4: systems of government
column5: elections
column6: and its relationship to capitalism) superficially. With the exception of a few (very occasional) facts
column7: the book provides little beyond what an educated person with an interest in democracy (e.g.
column8: college and reads the newspaper) already knows.  Part of the problem is the writing: it is meandering
column9: thus the book's 200 pages are not enough to go into any issue in depth. Part of the problem is a lack of focus
column10: for example
column11: Dahl spends several pages trying to show that assembly based democracy is not practical for large populations (which should be obvious)
column12: while not a single page on how democracies in practice assess the opinions of large populations (e.g.
column13: polling
column14: districting
column15: etc.).  A deeper problem may simply be that Dahl is a political "scientist". Law and economics seem to have long since stripped polisci of logic and empiricism
column16: both of which are missing here.  Why two stars (instead of one)? The book is well organized and does provide a framework for thinking about democracy; Dahl just never develops it

column1: This book struck me because it appears to address a wide issue in depth.  Unfortunately

column2: a series about which I'd developed rather mixed feelings. In order to get some perspective I decided to go back to one of Dr. Gregory's role models
column3: with the book that started the Alex Delaware franchise.  In the beginning
column4: When the Bough Breaks was a revelation. Flawlessly written
column5: with perfect pacing and a slowly building sense of menace
column6: this book is required reading for any fan of the genre. However
column7: problems develop about 2/3 of the way in.  *******SPOILERS FOLLOW********  Things took a turn for the worse when Detective Milo Sturgis dropped out of the action. At first I didn't notice he was gone because the pace was still holding up very well. In hindsight
column8: this awkward handling of a major character is indicative of Kellerman's unbalanced approach. My first real problem came with the overlong episode at Jedson College
column9: where the plot relies on dense passages of expository prose. This seemed like an immature writer's mistake
column10: and it was odd coming after so many pages of confident buildup.  Looking back on it now
column11: I wonder if Kellerman is one of those writers who is better at setting the stage than he is at leading the reader to a conclusion. My satisfaction rapidly evaporated as the story reached its climax. What started as a haunting meditation on loss and evil
column12: in the manner of Stephen White's Private Practices
column13: became overblown
column14: with too many plot elements and a dramatic showdown that could have been lifted right from the latest Hollywood action movie.  My final opinion is that for all of his flaws--the smugness
column15: the lapses into banality--Stephen White displays a craftsman's mastery of the mystery thriller
column16: a mastery that strangely eludes Kellerman. Two stars

column1: Losing a court case is like suffering a poker "bad beat."  Nobody really wants to hear your story
column2: and it's considered "whining" if you don't get over it after one beer.  Amazingly
column3: losers comprise more than 50% of all lawsuit participants.  Most go away muttering under their breath about judges who don't understand them.  Some can't get over their legal "bad beat" and write books about their loss.  So say it
column4: so be it.  The Discovery Institute has published their whine after the Dover bad beat.  Entitled "Traipsing Into Evolution
column5: it appeals to the court of public opinion.  Appeal denied.  This is a wretched book.  The Discovery Institute PR campaign for Intelligent Design bears a laughably strong resemblance to Baghdad Bob, the Iraqui Information" minister who claimed there weree no Americans in Iraq's capital city as those same Americans pounded up the stairs into his own studio.  His mere statements of fact served as their own proof
column6: no matter how outlandish.  Traipsing continues this M. O.  None of the factual assertions in this book are to be taken seriously.   The book overlooks a peculiar idiosyncrasy of courts.  Unlike Iraq's ministry of Information
column7: courts rely on something called "evidence."  There are two components to that concept.  First
column8: only evidence actually admitted in court "counts." Out of court self serving press releases are not evidence and don't count.  Second
column9: the evidence proffered in court must meet certain minimum requirements.  Witness testimony
column10: for example
column11: must be both under oath and subject to cross-examination.   That means witnesses must answer questions from an attorney who is not sympathetic to the witness's own position.  The witness  cannot decline to answer and the witness must tell the truth.  In the Dover trial
column12: the Intelligent Design side offered: (1) out of court press releases; (2) proffered witnesses who waffled
column13: equivocated
column14: and finally admitted the lack of factual support for ID when cross examined; and (3) some of the Intelligent Design witnesses got caught lying under oath.   The trial judge's opinion detailed ID's lack of evidence and the witness testimonial defects
column15: including the falsehoods
column16: throughout his 139 page decision.  Any intellectually honest post-mortem would have addressed these issues head on.  If you expect Traipsing to do so
column17: you'll be disappointed.  Traipsing argues that ID is good science and that it is not creationism. In "Bhagdad Bob" fashion
column18: the book offers Discovery Institute press releases as "evidence" in support The court rejected both propositions based on the evidence actually offered at trial.  As just one example
column19: two Discovery Fellows
column20: Michael Behe and Scott Minnich testified as experts.  Both were asked under oath if ID was science.  Both had the choice to answer truthfully or to lie and prevaricate.  To their credit
column21: they answered truthfully.  Minnich testified that ID was not science and Behe testified it was as scientific as astrology.  Based on this evidence from ID's own proponents
column22: the judge not surprisingly found that ID was not science.  Frankly
column23: the authors distort both the in-court and out of court evidence in their book.   The book makes much of the fact that the judge found a lack of peer reviewed literature and ignored the "vast" ID favorable literature enclosed in the book as Appendix B.  There are two reasons why the judge did not consider this literature.  (1) it was out of court hearsay
column24: not subject to cross examination; and (2) It is not scientific research
column25: it is essentially propaganda. This second point is why nobody was willing to actually testify in court that such peer reviewed ID-specific scientific research existed.    If you are interested in what really happened
column26: get it from the horse's mouth.  Read the opinion itself and the actual evidence and trial testimony.  Both are online.

column1: I am not an accountant

column5: I then proceed to this book.  And what I learned is that accounting has many
column6: many categories of events to be accounted
column7: lots and lots of counter-intuitive conventions
column8: jargon galore
column9: and an unending supply of seemingly arbitrary rules.  What I did *not* learn from this book is that accounting is very logical
column10: an entire system built on two postulates (to borrow some mathematical vocabulary).  Happily
column11: I share a 45 minute commute with an accountant friend
column12: and he enlightened me.  But without the individual tutoring

column14: since after all most readers are interesting in acquiring skills
column15: not contemplating beauty.  Unfortunately
column16: this is a car wreck of a a "how to" book.  The text is wordy
column17: amiguous

column19: and accounting is probably one of the most important inventions of all times.  This book does not do the subject justice

It should have focused more on Fong See and his life as opposed to then focusing on his childrens' lives and going on and on from there. His story is undeniably both interesting and troubling- it depicts "American" prejudice
column8: racism and the difficulties facing minorities in this country.  However
column9: it would have been more poingnant if it stood alone as the focal point of the novel.

 I hated this book! I usually love Coulters work and her heroes, but Anthony was just revolting! The rape, the beating, everything about the way he treated her, including the whole 'I loved your mother, you'll do as the next best thing' just left me wishing that another character (even Edward)would come save poor Cassie from this monstrous man! He just completely degraded her. So what if he loved her - move on, get over it. Personally I see his actions as a deranged stalker, not a man in love. I disagree with all the other reviewers who state that we shouldn't apply modern values to historical romances - hello? If I want realism, I'll read a history book. This is supposed to be fiction! If it was really accurate he probably would have no teeth and smell bad! Plus, we as the readers should identify with the main characters. Cassie's decision to love the man who raped her just left me cold. My kind of heroine would have fought and made him pay (maybe castrated him after beating him thoroughly!) If you like romances - stay away 
  One Deadly Night" may be the most unusual true crime tale this reviewer has read.  This is entirely due to the fact that author Glatt
column7: or his publisher
column8: rushed ODN to print far too soon. The following will attempt to justify that charge: David Camm was a former Indiana State Trooper. He may have been a fine cop but it appears he was anything but a good husband or a nice guy. (There are no crimes attached to those personal shortcomings!).  One evening in September 2000
column9: Camm's wife and two children were murdered in the garage of their New Albany
column10: Indiana home.  The setting is a Louisville suburb
column11: not a remote town in the cornfields.  ODN is told mostly from a prosecutorial viewpoint.  The investigating State Police fingered DC as the perp from the very outset. Virtually no effort was made
column12: at least within the pages of ODN
column13: to identify another suspect or accomplice.  This reader had the suspicion that Camm made enemies among his fellow troopers while still in uniform and was receiving some serious payback.  It is almost meaningless that that DC is found guilty of murder only to have that conviction overturned. What happened next? My amazon friends have 2 choices in securing an answer: 1) Do a web search on David Camm to be bought up to date as of March 7
column14: 2006.  2) Wait until the case has COMPLETELY wound its' way through the legal system. Perhaps then author Glatt will produce a comprehensive-and FINAL! - story on the events of that "deadly Indiana night" of September 2000. In that forthcoming final version
column15: one hopes the author will shed light on the urgency to rush a garden variety
column16: uncompelling murder case into print. Judging by the reprint history ODN is selling well but promoting an unresolved case is plainly and simply misleading. For the moment
column17: ODN is not recommended to my amazon friends.

column1: I believe Ayn Rand's writings are very destructive. And this isn't because                      of her highly un-original philosophy. No
column2: the reason for this is the                      powerful grip the books has on her  followers. In her books they find                      justification for  behaving in a anti-social manner that is slowly destroying                       the fabric of the societies of the Western World. This egoism is                       supposedly derived from "reason". In the real world  however there is no                      reason for people not to find  fulfillment and meaning from helping others                      and caring  for their family and friends. The accusation that "altruism"
column3: i.e.                      decency and goodness
column4: leads to tyranny is nothing  but products of a very                      paranoid mind. The craziest  thing about this though is the fact that Ayn                      Rand has  been raised to a saint-like status by her followers. No                       disagreement with her writings is ever accepted and if you disagree you                       are an evil communist/collectivist. To be a true  individualist you must                      agree with everything she has  ever written. Isn't this collectivism in a true                      sense?  No
column5: says her followers
column6: those views are derived by reason and                       must therefore be share by all intelligent human beings. Pretty  scary!!                      Note that Objectivism
column7: like Marxism
column8: Freudianism and Jungianism
column9: is a                      closed system of  thought in the sense that any critisism of the system is                       automatically seen as a symptom of unreason. This is what makes                       Objectivism a religion rather than a philosophy or scientific  method. And                      this is also the reason for the fanatical  behavior of her disciples. At best                      her books are  useful self help guides
column10: but this is also true of for example                       the Bible or the writings of Jung

column1: The amount of praise given to this work does not surprise me given that there is a widespread
column2: yet subtle
column3: socialist movement in America as well as in Europe.  Despite this
column4: the book is a failed attempt at reconciling the ideal with reality.  Rawls commits one of the many age-old flaws of collectivism
column5: attempting to force morality on immoral beings. Rawls' entire work is fundamentally flawed in that the hypothetical situation from which the entire theory relies
column6: selectively allows certain knowledge
column7: assumptions
column8: etc. while conveniently eliminating others.  For instance
column9: empirical evidence that shows capitalism outperforms other economic systems cannot be known in the original position.  This is profound when one considers that we live in a hostile world that requires nations to invest in security of which economic power is imperative.  Thus
column10: capitalism may be a necessary injustice in order to safeguard liberal democracy.  If we compare the human condition prior to capitalism
column11: one can see that perhaps a collectivist system that may contribute to capitalism's downfall is immoral
column12: if it leads us back in this direction.  Consequentalism perhaps?  Despite this
column13: the people in the original position cannot have this knowledge.  Therefore
column14: information that is direly relevant to the construction of a social system in a hostile world cannot be used in determining its structure.  Somehow though
column15: the people do understand the important of the right to vote
column16: equality
column17: etc. This is absurd and impractical.  Rationale beings need to analyze as much information as is available and pertinent to any decisions they make.  Rawls continuously attempts to explain his "tweaks" as rationale but it is obvious that they are all implemented in order to discount human nature and proceed in theoretical terms.  On a side note
column18: Rawls' first principle calls for the right to vote
column19: what would his state do if citizens began to vote for a more capitalistic system that defied his "justice"?  Iron fist?  Nevertheless
column20: it is quite obvious what Rawls is attempting here.  In a hypothetical situation where we all have to fear being born without intelligence
column21: strength
column22: status etc. we will take the safe route and ensure ourselves the highest index of goods.  This may be true
column23: or it may not (human nature seems to embrace risk taking) however this situation is irrelevant because of its exclusion of relevant information.  Hobbes for instance accepted human nature and the potential for a wide array of circumstances in his hypothetical Natural Condition.  While Rawls may have some strong arguments in declaring that his two principles are the epitome absolute justice
column24: this does not mean they are practical in a hostile world.  Essentially
column25: what Rawls is saying is that none of us deserved to be born intelligent
column26: responsible
column27: hard working
column28: but that we were simply lucky in the natural lottery.  Because of this arbitrary distribution
column29: he believes that we all must compensate for those unfortunate souls that were born unintelligent
column30: lazy
column31: and perhaps even immoral!  I'd admonish Rawls not to attempt applying his insane reasoning to the criminal justice system (Poor
column32: unfortunate murderer).  If Rawls believes that the laziest
column33: dumbest
column34: and most immoral person still deserves a living wage despite not working
column35: he has contradicted himself in that this justifies slavery
column36: forcing individuals to work for other individuals without compensation.  This simply cannot be justice as "fairness".  Nevertheless
column37: I'd recommend it to all free market advocates simply to strengthen their positions.  As a warning however
column38: be prepared for a work that lacks brevity
column39: organization
column40: coherence
column41: and most importantly
column42: reality
