column1: Despite not being written on the packaging or website my HP iPaq RX3417 was compatible with this keyboard.  Unfortunatly the software supplied was extremely bad
column2: clogging my PDA making it run very slowely. As well as this
column3: it also flickered when in use making the settings for the keyboard very difficult to change.  In terms of hardware
column4: I found the size and position of keys to be the biggest problem. While targus does include all 5 rows of a standard keyboard
column5: it shrinks the top row (numbers) and the bottom row (space bar). This makes it very difficult to use the space bar (which is for some reason split into three parts) and the numbers (which could have been made full size as there is nothing else in the way). I found myself constantly not hitting the right key or not hitting the right key hard enough for the key to register. In terms of key position
column6: there is a gap between the keys on the left side and right side of the keyboard making hitting the keys in the middle very difficult. Some keys are also very small (e.g. the right shift key and backspace) making them difficult to use (strange considering they are used a lot on keyboards).  One of the biggest problems I had with the keyboard was the lack of proper arrow keys. Targus includes an oval shaped four direction button that controls a mouse cursor that appears on the screen. This mouse cursor is useful
column7: but needs to be supplemented with normal Up
column8: Down
column9: Left and Right keys which are needed when typing to go back to another part of the document. Using the mouse to do this is very frustrating.  The final negative thing about this keyboard was the price. I paid AUD$149.95 for this keyboard. Doing some research on the internet found better models (i.e. Think Outside Stowaway IR Keyboard) available for less than half the price (around AUD$70) and bluetooth keyboards available for less than AUD$190. I think it might be about time Targus releases a new model PDA keyboard with a design and software that are suitable for the use the keyboard will get. No more tiny keys and no more than two space bars

column1: "The Door In The Floor" is difficult to like
column2: even
column3: (or perhaps especially)
column4: if you're a fan of John Irving's book
column5: "A Widow For One Year
column6: which was the source of this film.   The movie is dark, depressing, & slow-moving. It also showcases the least likable characters from the book. To make matters worse, it focuses only on the first third of the novel's story, which leaves us with an entire movie about an alienated, (& alienating), couple's suffering. The film is completely devoid of the novel's interesting & more enjoyable journey through this tragic period of a family's life & into the more fulfilling chapters in the lives of characters who aren't well developed in the film, but who are central to the book's satisfying end to an otherwise hopelessly sad story!   This may give you an idea why the film wasn't very successful with audiences.   The theme is of deep personal loss and the devastating effects it can have on people. Unfortunately, the film version of the story concentrates almost entirely on the agony experienced by the parents, played by Jeff Bridges & Kim Basinger, in the aftermath of the accidental death of their two teenage sons. It wallows in the empty chasm that's grown between them & delves into the sad, meaningless, & even cruel love affairs they each engage in, in vain attempts to ease their sorrows & escape the pain of the love lost between them & of course, the greatest loss, the loss of their sons. The film also highlights the rather ugly way this couple inflicts damage upon the people they use for this purpose.   And finally, we witness the pain of their very young daughter, who was born out of yet more of the parent's attempts to fill their empty, sad lives, and we're treated to a view of her pitiful childhood, growing up with parents who truly aren't there."   The greatest mystery for me is why the screenwriter chose to tell just a small slice of the story of this great novel
column7: and even worse
column8: why they chose to "bring to life" only the most depressing and frankly least interesting parts of it! If the theme of loss is one you're very interested in
column9: you might find this movie quite affecting.  As for me
column10: a great fan of the book
column11: I can only hope that someday someone makes a better & more complete adaptation of this great book. It's not nearly as desperate & sad a story as this film version!  On subsequent viewings I've grown to appreciate this film a bit more. Taken completely apart from the novel
column12: it's not a "bad" film. Undoubtedly

column1: The trust a young reader places in a writer is something to appreciate and value. Many young readers have been following this promising series for several years and have paid the writer with their return through a dozen books and waiting for the conclusion to this saga. The writer has commited the ultimate betrayal to his young readers in delivering this last book. The book is poorly written and reveals a very undisciplined writer. Perhaps it was too much success-too soon
column2: or an editor who rushed this last book to publishing which led to this fiasco. It is disappointing that the writer did not value the many young minds who waited for the conclusion. The rambling shows the control of an alcoholic and the shoddy conclusion reveals a lack of creativity. It is clear that he did not give enough time and thought to develop something with more control and imagination. It is sad that many children will approach other serial writers skeptically after this miserable ending to the miserable series

column1: I recommend you not buy this book or cd.  I listened to the CD and it was too elementary
This book speculates about both the advance of computer technology in the 21st century and the socio-political response to it.  Although it is peppered with a few interesting notions worth skimming
column2: much of the speculation is unreasonable and philosophically naive.  In the first chapter
column3: Kurzweil attempts to lay a sort of theoretical framework for his speculations
column4: which boils down to his belief that Moore's Law is just one instance of a cosmic principle of exponential advance which explains everything from the first second of the universe after the Big Bang to the evolution of life on Earth and now the evolution of technology.  The second chapter argues that it is possible for an intelligence to create something more intelligent than itself:  just as evolution "intelligently" created us
column5: we will (soon!) create computers which will build machines of far greater cognitive ability than us.  It is indeed intriguing to consider that someday machines will outperform humans in many ways
column6: but the book to this point is best skimmed
column7: because there's actually very little substance and a lot of dry
column8: pseudo-intellectual filler.  Chapter 3 examines the philosophical problem that is going to be brought to the forefront by super-advanced computers:  what is consciousness
column9: and can machines possess it?  Kurzweil unimpressively touches on a handful of schools of thought here (his sentences on Descartes made me wonder if he has read anything on the subject besides pop philosophy)
column10: though he does not try to decide between them.  Instead
column11: his prediction is social:  eventually machines will be accepted as real people -- just as real people will physically merge with technology -- even if that sounds bizarre to us now.  This theme comes up again and again
column12: and it proves to be one of the only thought-provoking issues of the book.  Chapters 4 and 5 talk about the field of artificial intelligence
column13: where it has been
column14: and where it needs to go.  In a section entitled "The Formula for Intelligence"
column15: Kurzweil provides his recipe for the strong AI of the future:  recursion
column16: neural nets
column17: and genetic algorithms -- all taking hints from the reverse engineering of the human brain.  This wishful thinking is one of the Achilles' heels of this book.  For a software entrepreneuer
column18: Kurzweil is strangely blind to the evidence:  software is hardly becoming more complex or "intelligent" at all
column19: let alone exponentially.  Today's software systems are perhaps bigger but not significantly "smarter" than systems of past decades
column20: and software quality continues to barely meet the lowest of expectations.  Despite Moore's Law and the faith that it will continue to provide more and more cycles in the hardware world
column21: progress in the world of software seems
column22: to this software engineer of 15 years
column23: to be nearly a flat line
column24: not an exponential curve.  Just compare how many hundreds of man-years have gone into the lastest version of Windows
column25: versus what it would take to design and implement Kurzweil's ideal of software that is able to write more powerful software.  Part of the problem may be that Kurzweil simply ignores the fields of cognitive psychology and epistemology
column26: which are in their infancy.  He does not seem to even be aware of the issues in these fields which would have to be solved (probably by geniuses) in order to create "strong AI."  Instead
column27: the solutions he predicts are purely materialistic:  brain deciphering
column28: massively parallel hardware
column29: and genetic algorithms.  Part 2 of the book focuses on potential technologies.  The most powerful computers he speculates about are quantum computers
column30: and he doesn't waste any time before asserting that someday we will be able to download the entirety of a brain into a quantum computer
column31: so that the computer will in effect have a clone of that person's mind.  Kurzweil
column32: in his materialism
column33: does not seem to even be aware that there is a philosophical argument that this is impossible.  He also speculates about nanotechnologies and how they will eventually give us a unprecented ability to manipulate physical reality.  Part 3 of the book is comprised of specific predictions for 2009
column36: and 2099.  This book was written in 1999
column37: and we can already see that some of his 2009 predictions are either just simple extensions of things we were starting to see in 1999
column38: while others wildly miss the mark
column39: such as:  "the majority of reading is done on displays"
column40: "the majority of text is created using continuous speech recognition"
column41: and "intelligent roads are in use
column42: primarily for long-distance travel."  That Kurzweil could be so far off in his 10 year predictions does not bode well for his 20-
column44: and 100-year predictions.  Indeed
column45: his predictions for 2019 sound like a science fiction novel
column46: and of the ones that sound plausible I think he must be off by at least 30 years.  His speculations for 2029 are just fantastic.  In general he seems to "predict" based on the assumption that new technologies will be deployed as soon as they are available
column47: underestimating a myriad of resisting factors:  legal
column48: political
column49: social
column50: market
column51: scientific
column52: etc.  Ultimately this book can be fun for skimming and raises a couple of thought-provoking issues
column53: but as speculating about technology more than 10 years in the future is necessarily a foolish activity
column54: there's plenty of foolishness to be found in here

column1: A bit of context: I am an intermediate photographer recently introduced to digital SLR through the purchase of a Nikon D70.  I am well-versed in general photographic knowlege and the theories behind color management and light in the context of digital photography.  I purchased this book hoping that it would help me to understand enough about color management to at least start asking the right questions about how to apply color management to my setup.  I became so frustrated with it that I've had to stop reading it several times just to collect myself.  In no particular order
column2: the book is flawed in the following ways:  * It is not well written.  I stumble over poor writing more than the average reader
column3: but this book simply had too much akward prose and was overly conversational.  Unfortunately
column4: this poor writing was more than just a distraction: important points were frequently lost to unclear writing. * Full of marginally useful examples.  The author provides step-by-step instructions for numerous software programs (and a few pieces of hardware too) that are completely useless for those of us who don't have the software (or hardware). * Many "tips" revealed to be unimportant.  One of my biggest pet peeves was that on several occassions the author provided lengthy explantions of processes
column5: features
column6: or concepts
column7: only to wrap up his discussion with "but all of this isn't really important
column8: so you don't need to worry about it." * Poor organization.  The book could have benefited significantly from a reorganization around those tasks that the average reader was likely to try to do.  I found myself finishing the book still unclear where to even start thinking about my color management setup
column9: and with basic questions still unanswered. * Meaningless examples.  The author provides (some very striking) images in support of his ideas
column10: but many are not directly related his points (single images with captions like "Professional photographer X uses color management to make sure that the colors he sees on his screen are the same as those on the final print")  I give it two stars instead of one because there is some useful information in the text -- it's just incredibly hard to find amid all of the clutter

column2: Marshall writes that:    David Friedman sees such agencies as both brokers of mini- social contracts and producers of 'laws' which conform to the market demand for rules to regulate commerce. Each person would be free to subscribe to a protective association of his choice
column3: since 'Protection from coercion is an economic good.' Apart from adumbrating The Machinery of Freedom (1973)
column4: Friedman has popularized Hayek's defense of capitalism as the best antidote to the serfdom of collectivism in books with such self-explanatory titles as Capitalism and Freedom (1962) and Free to Choose (1979).  The true author of Capitalism and Freedom and Free to Choose is of course Milton Friedman
column5: David Friedman's non-anarchist father. Milton Friedman is not mentioned in the two preceding pages of the chapter; and in any case "Friedman" clearly is meant to refer to David Friedman. (Nor is Milton Friedman in the index or bibliography of the book
column6: although at least Milton Friedman's books are omitted from the bibliography rather than attributed to David Friedman's authorship a second time.)   This error is so egregious that the reader can only conclude that Peter Marshall presumes to write about books that he has never even seen the cover of
column7: much less read. Whether Marshall corrected it in a subsequent edition
column8: or whether the error was simply corrected by the transcriber of the widely available Internet exerpt
column9: I do not know. But even if the correction was Marshall's
column10: for this kind of error to have made it into a published book speaks volumes.   On the same page
column11: Marshall writes that:   The writings of Ayn Rand
column12: a refugee from the Soviet Union
column13: best represent the intellectual background to the new right-wing libertarianism in the United States. In her The Virtue of Selfishness: A New Concept of Egoism (1964)
column14: she attempted a philosophical defence of egoism while in her novels she portrayed a superior individual fighting the forces of collectivism
column15: particularly in the form of the State. Her superior individual
column16: driven by a Nietzschean will to power

column21: the paragraph immediately ends. The next paragraph begins
column22: "Amongst anarcho-capitalist apologists
column23: the economist Murray Rothbard is probably the most aware of the anarchist tradition."   Again
column24: this outrageous error has been corrected in the Internet excerpt of Demanding the Impossible. But it provides additional proof that Peter Marshall presumes to write about books and authors that he has never read. Ayn Rand's attack on anarcho-capitalism (in "The Nature of Government
column25: one essay in her The Virtue of Selfishness) is so clear that Marshall could only make this error by failing to have even read the author whose views he is describing.   These are only two of Marshall's numerous factual errors which demonstrate a shocking lack of basic standards of scholarship. After all, a book is not a Usenet posting; one is supposed to spend months or years in study, fact-checking, re-writing, and so on.   Some similar errors appear in Ulrike Heider's Anarchism: Left, Right and Green. Once again, there are errors so gross that the only possible explanation is that Heider presumes to write about books she has never read.   A few examples of her poor scholarship:    Menger is considered the founder of the Austrian School of Economics
column26: which continued to refine its theory of monetary value until the middle of the 20th century. The most prominent descendent of this school of thought is is monetarist Milton Friedman
column27: the economic authority for such politicians as Richard Nixon
column28: Ronald Reagan
column29: Margaret Thatcher
column30: and others." Anarchism: Left
column31: Right
column32: and Green
column33: p.100.  Milton Friedman is not and never has had any affiliation with the Austrian School. In fact
column34: he is the most famous member of the rival Chicago School
column35: which even a minimal study of the differences between free-market economists would have revealed.   "If it weren't for their obsession with work and their misanthropic outlook
column36: one might mistake Rand's heroes for left-wing bohemians. They are always Anglo-Saxon Americans." ibid
column37: p.105  Francisco d'Anconia
column38: one of the four major heroic characters in Ayn Rand's Atlas Shrugged is of South American nationality.   "Roark's rival
column39: the mediocre architect Peter Keaton..."ibid  The character's name is in fact Peter Keating. While the error is trivial
column40: it does indicate that Heider sees no need to get the basic facts straight when she discusses a book. The Fountainhead is divided into four sections
column41: each named for one major character; "Peter Keating" is the title of the first section. It would be very hard to miss
column42: unless you never read the book (or wrote from memory years afterwards).   Reversing her previous confusion about the Austrian vs. the Chicago schools of economics
column43: Heider appears to attribute monetarist policy prescriptions to Rothbard: "The monetarist road out of such misery must lead through a depression
column44: the 'painful but necessary process by which the free market rids itself of the excesses and errors of the boom.' [quotation Rothbard's] Rothbard recommends that the government do the exact opposite of what the Keynesians suggest: it should simply abandon its policy of inflation by giving the free market reign and by reinstating the gold standard." ibid
column45: p.131.  Again
column46: Rothbard spent the better part of his academic career attacking monetarism and the Chicago school of economics with which monetarism is associated.  I have been informed by admirers of Murray Bookchin that Heider's work contains similar gross errors about eco-anarchism. Since this is not my field of expertise
column47: I do not presume to point them out
column48: but it would not surprise me.   It is one thing to violently disagree with an author
column49: and to express one's disagreement in a book. It is another matter entirely to get basic facts wrong; so wrong
column50: in fact

I feel really bad for those poor students of Mr. Pearce who don't drop out of his class the first week.  This is the first book on public speaking that I've read where I honestly haven't taken anything from this book
column2: and I've read about five.  He talks about all of the mechanics of public speaking
column3: but something big is missing from this book.  Also
column4: leadership via public speaking
column5: which seems to be the titular topic of this book
column6: is missing from the pages.  Mr. Pearce reminds me of one of my statistics professors.  This professor
column7: which I'll call Mr. Banal
column8: was a very smart person
column9: had studied a lot
column10: was up on the current statistics methodologies
column11: and was a nice person.  However
column12: Mr. Banal's lecture consisted almost entirely of an analysis of what he thought of the textbook.  Mr. Banal always had some new "insight"--which usually amounted to a very minor disagreement that he had with the author of the text.  He talked about this minor disagreement for the entire lecture hour.  I think that doing this allowed him to feel good about himself
column13: because he was proving to the students that he was smarter than the author of the text.  This was really confusing to me.  Who should I believe
column14: Mr. Banal or the author of the statistics text?  The author seemed a lot more interesting (which is funny considering the subject)
column15: but Mr. Banal was the one who ultimately would be testing me.  This is what Mr. Pearce does in his book.  He is constantly rewriting speeches of others into a "better speech."  A really funny example of this occurs during the end of the book
column16: where he's quoting Anita Roddick
column17: managing director of The Body Shop International.  Roddick is an excellent public speaker
column18: and he quotes often from one of her speeches
column19: which is probably the most interesting part of the book.  Toward the end
column20: Mr. Pearce cherry picks a paragraph from her speech and reworks it.  The initial paragraph wasn't all that bad
column21: but Mr. Pearce's "improved" version of it was terrible.  This is the same kind of difference between a sports commentator and an avid fan.  The sports commentator will describe the athlete
column22: what the athlete did during the performance
column23: and trace the effects of the athlete's performance.  This is very complex and requires a lot of skill.  The avid fan will say things like
column24: "I would have done this...I would have done that."  This requires very little skill at all.  Mr. Pearce is the avid fan

column1: Throughout the 1990's
column2: American popular culture was awash with frisson-producing paranoid fantasies ranging from the hit TV show
column3: "The X Files"
column4: to accusations that the President's critics were being sytematically murdered by methods and persons unknown.  Observers began to notice what scholar Daniel Pipes called "fusion paranoia"; i.e.
column5: the blending of disparate (and sometimes wildly contradictory) elements from Christian apocalyptic rhetoric
column6: UFOlogy
column7: 'moral panic'
column8: millennial fears of what the year 2000 might bring
column9: techno-thriller fiction
column10: and what has been dubbed "the paranoid style" in U.S. politics.  Conservative Catholics proved no less prone than fundamentalist Protestants to being swept up in the surrounding culture's manias and follies.  It would be nice to think that the apocalyptic fever has disappeared now that the turn of the millennium is several years behind us having ushered in nothing more remarkable than the failure of widespread predictions that the world's computers would all crash on cue at midnight.  Unfortunately
column11: the continuing incredible success of the (at last count) 12-book "Left Behind" series by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins militates against such comforting thoughts.  It was probably inevitable that a Catholic writer would try their hand at this sort of thing
column12: and so we have Michael D. O'Brien's "Father Elijah:  An Apocalypse" along with the rest of the novels in his "Children of the Last Days" series.  Needless to say
column13: as a Roman Catholic
column14: Mr. O'Brien writes with considerably more polish than his benighted Protestant brethren; he also seems able to create characters that have somewhat more depth to them than paper dolls.  Since the author is not shackled by the constraints of biblical literalism
column15: he can also dispense with bizarre and off-putting fixtures from the Book of Revelations
column16: such as giant six-winged brazen locusts whose stings kill
column17: and other equally gory visions.  Despite granting the above points in their favor
column18: his books still hew with amazing precision to the hackneyed formula laid down previously by such Protestant fundamentalist authors as Frank Peretti and Tim LaHaye. In this book
column19: Father Elijah
column20: a Jewish Holocaust survivor turned Catholic priest is dispatched to North America on a perilous secret mission by the Vatican. This is nothing less than to make contact with the Anti-Christ to dissuade him from his evil plan. At the risk of spoiling things
column21: it will be noted here that this infernal personage turns out not to be Nicolae Carpathia
column22: Secretary-General of the U.N.
column23: but the President. President of what is made none too clear; Father Elijah's mission takes him to Canada. Considering that this book was published the same year as the Clinton impeachment extravaganza
column24: faithful Christian readers should have no need of having the answer spelled out for them. (All good Christians know that Bill Clinton is the beast with seven heads and ten horns described in Revelations 13.) As with similar-themed books
column25: there has to be at least one token Jewish good guy
column26: presumably to ward off accusations of anti-Semitism.  While Mr. O'Brien has the good taste not to mention what lies in store for those Jews obstinate enough not to convert to Catholicism
column27: other sowers of apocalyptic panic more than make up for this deficiency. (Hint: Jews should pack enough asbestos underwear to last for a long trip.)   Other books in this series take the form of `prequels' and sequels
column28: with settings extending from
column29: roughly
column30: the Paleolithic age (Note to reader: pace
column31: this is meant ironically) to the near future. In the novels set in contemporaneous times such as "Father Elijah"
column32: "Eclipse of the Sun" and "Plague Journal"
column33: the by-now tiresome tropes of contemporary religious fiction are all wheeled out.   Among these are:  the "soft" totalitarian state that persecutes Christians. (Holy Herbert Marcuse
column34: Batman! Self-pitying Christians in North America who whine about "persecution" should be shipped--perhaps one way--to the Sudan to see what genuine religious persecution is really about.  They might also take in the killing fields of the former Yugoslavia lest they think that religious massacres and expulsions by Christians are something from the remote past.) Noble
column35: upstanding Christian parents
column36: who live in fear of having their children torn from them because they are insufficiently `politically correct'. (Will that hoary clich never die?  In case anyone has been living under a rock--or perhaps a remote cabin in Ontario; it is now conservatism that has degenerated into a hare-brained hash of contradictory `correct' opinions
column37: all bound together as tightly as the rods of a Roman fasces.) "Feminists"
column38: an epithet usually used by conservatives to mean any woman not a doormat
column39: are portrayed in the usual lurid fashion practically as evil succubae; the fons et origo of the Universe's every ill. (Quick!  Can anyone name a single leading present-day feminist now that Betty Friedan is dead and Gloria Steinem long since retired?)  Evil sodomites are presented in time-honored fashion as dissolute and sad--that is
column40: when not fiendishly conspiring with the other standard conservative bugbears to destroy civilization in a fashion similar to "The Protocols of the Learned Elders of Zion".  Top all this off with some Tom Clancy-style high adventure
column41: and voila! There you have it.  Where are Graham Greene
column42: Flannery O'Connor
column43: and Georges Bernanos when you really need them?   It may seem like breaking a butterfly on the wheel to hold up grotesque twaddle like these books for pitiless inspection in the light of common day.  It is not.  During the mid-1980's the publishers of this series of books produced and distributed a truly tenebrous and evil tome
column44: "The AIDS Cover-Up?".  This vile book deliberately aimed to terrorize with spurious projections that AIDS would kill tens of millions of Americans within a decade. To forestall such a cataclysm
column45: it advised that all gays--much less anyone found to be HIV-positive through mandatory testing--be rounded-up and forcibly interned in concentration camps.  According to conservative science writer Michael Fumento (who by his own account lost his job with the Reagan administration for criticizing the book--and the morals of the people touting it)
column46: copies of it could be seen on desks all over official Washington in those days.  There are probably still some conservatives who treasure this theo-porn
column47: if only behind the door.  None of the horrors either predicted or recommended by the book ever came to pass
column48: but it was a near thing.  The moral of this story?  Ideas
column49: even the most vicious or worthless
column50: have consequences.  At a time when fantasy and reality are becoming blurred in many minds
column51: books such as Mr. O'Brien's cannot be excused merely because they are classed under "Fiction". People who gabble about the `End Times' in this fashion are (to use a formulation of Orwell's) like those who play with fire who seemingly don't realize that fire is hot and can burn.  If your opponents are not merely mistaken or even just wrong
column52: but are conscious servants of the devil.... Well
column53: there are plenty of deluded souls out there who may decide to suit actions to words.   This series of books (and similar ones by other authors) share a rare distinction: they get it completely upside down. Instead of being threatened by "the dictatorship of relativism"

column59: indefinite detention without trial of American citizens and others neither charged nor convicted of any crime

column62: or Franklin Roosevelt during World War II did anything like this.  Meanwhile

column3: and I got nothing worthwhile from the experience.  What stood out to me the most is the fact that the main character's motivation never really made sense.  The plot construction hinges on Claudia concluding that her sex appeal must be waning and deciding to practice her flirting skills by striking up a conversation with one new guy every day.  So far
column4: so good.  The problem is that she comes to this conclusion after only one week of being single
column5: and immediately after some random guy at a party tries to kiss her.  Claudia successfully extricates herself from the guy trying to make out with her
column6: is complimented on the way she handled the guy by her Crush
column7: and what she takes from those back-to-back experiences is that she must not be very attractive to guys.  That makes no sense whatsoever.  Seriously
column8: that's precisely the lack of internal logic and appropriate plot development you can look forward to in this book. Claudia is swarmed with male attention to an unrealistic degree (her ex-boyfriend is trying to get back together with her
column9: band members that she interviews proposition her
column10: the most socially important guy at her first Greek party hits on her
column11: guys at the gym ogle her
column12: a really great guy sees her at a coffee shop once and is so taken with her that he arranges a way to meet cute with her later) and yet she keeps telling us in her narrative that she lacks confidence in her ability to attract men.  I was never able to really connect with Claudia and I did not think that her experiences had any ring of truth to them.  It's a fast read

The average southern yeoman may not have owned slaves, but because slave-owning was the highest mark of status in southern society, he certainly hoped to SOMEDAY own a slave, or two, or three...Many southerners fought for the right to maintain slavery, in the hope that someday they might own them. Read REAL history. It is not Northern Biased

it is simply conclusive fact based on imperical evidence.    
 I zipped through the first 100 pages of this book unable to put it down.  Unfortuneately the author seems to run out of gas after that.  The main character just goes on a big, boring sight seeing tour.  It reminded me of that show on the Travel Channel where that girl visits hotel after hotel fawning over the interior design. There is not a hint of conflict until the final pages and then it's very short-lived and quickly followed by one of the worst non endings I've ever read.  The book just stops.  Not a hint of resolution or even a cliff hanger pointing to a sequel.  It's a shame because Grimsley had some great concepts to work with.  In my experience novels that mix technology with magic usually fail at both, but Grimsley had a workable foundation he could have developed into something unique if he had focused on the SF concepts instead of minutiae.    Once in a while the characters stop admiring the drapes long enough to notice the GIANT FREAKIN' PORTAL BETWEEN TWO WORLDS--but enough about that.   Gee, what a lovely sofa..

column1: I'm a psychiatric nurse. Peter Breggin is well known in the field of psychiatric medicine as being anti-all drugs.  Has prozac been overprescribed or mis-prescribed? sure. but this drug and the class it belongs to have helped WAY more people than they hurt. penicillin and other antibiotics can kill you too if you're allergic and don't know it. and antibiotics are WAY over prescribed if you ask me and other professionals. i've worked in state psychiatric hospitals and i've seen a LOT of people who only got out and back to the world because of medication.  i would hate to think that a book like this would turn back the clock to the old days when there was no medication and people wasted their whole lives in the hospital. GET A GRIP: ANYthing you put in your body has side effects and you can die from taking too much Tylenol
column2: too. picking on this drug is a cheap tric

There are limited texts on East Asian history and it is unfortunate that this author decided to spike his with unabashed personal commentary.  Overall
column2: the content is impressive but some of Murphey's claims are hard to stomach.      An example of such outlandish claims is the theme in later chapters that American Cold War policy drove Asian Communists to a harder line by resisting them with military campaigns and non-democratic governments.  Murphey insinuates that Mao Zedong
column3: Ho Chi Min
column4: and other Communist leaders had more moderate programs planned for when they came to power but were forced into reeducation programs and political purges because of American policy.    Besides this outright opinion paraded as fact
column5: Murphey also annoyingly snickers and gripes with hyphenated and parenthetical commentary.  There are also facts suspiciously left out.  For example
column6: Murphey spends a great deal of effort detailing conservative corruption in earlier Korean politics but mentions nothing of the massive scandals accompanying the end of Kim Dae-Jun's term.  Lastly
column7: many of Murphey's dubious claims can not be investigated by the readers.  Facts are not referenced and a bibliography of only 40 sources is available at the end -- suspiciously thin for a work of this magnitude and considering the many "facts" quoted.  Murphey's bias and this lack of sourcing make this book marginally useful for graduate level research
column8: unless one is willing to accept the good professor at his word.  The Ivory Tower is alive and well in Ann Arbor

column1: 1. The Twelve Steps do not work as a program of recovery from drug or alcohol problems.  The A.A. failure rate ranges from 95% to 100%. Sometimes
column2: the A.A. success rate is actually less than zero
column3: which means that A.A. indoctrination is positively harmful to people
column4: and prevents recovery. Some tests have shown that even receiving no treatment at all for alcoholism is much better than receiving A.A. treatment:  One of the most enthusiastic boosters of Alcoholics Anonymous
column5: Professor George Vaillant of Harvard University
column6: who is also a member of the Board of Trustees of Alcoholics Anonymous World Services
column7: Inc. (AAWS)
column8: showed by his own 8 years of testing of A.A. that A.A. was worse than useless -- that it didn't help the alcoholics any more than no treatment at all
column9: and it had the highest death rate of any treatment program tested -- a death rate that Professor Vaillant himself described as "appalling". While trying to prove that A.A. treatment works
column10: Professor Vaillant actually proved that A.A. kills. After 8 years of A.A. treatment
column11: the score with Dr. Vaillant's first 100 alcoholic patients was: 5 sober
column12: 29 dead
column13: and 66 still drinking.  (Nevertheless
column14: Vaillant is still a Trustee of Alcoholics Anonymous
column15: and he still wants to send all alcoholics to A.A. anyway
column16: to "get an attitude change by confessing their sins to a high-status healer." That is cult religion
column17: not a treatment program for alcoholism.)  The A.A. dropout rate is terrible. Most people who come to A.A. looking for help in quitting drinking are appalled by the narrow-minded atmosphere of fundamentalist religion and faith-healing. The A.A. meeting room has a revolving door. The therapists
column18: judges
column19: and parole officers (many of whom are themselves hidden members of A.A. or N.A.) continually send new people to A.A.
column20: but those newcomers vote with their feet once they see what A.A. really is. Even A.A.'s own triennial surveys
column21: conducted by the A.A. headquarters (the GSO)
column22: say that:  81% of the newcomers are gone within 30 days
column23: 90% are gone in 3 months
column24: and  95% are gone at the end of a year.  That automatically gives A.A. a failure rate of at least 95%. But the GSO does not count all of those people who only attend a few meetings before quitting -- they don't qualify as "members". (That amounts to "cherry-picking".) If we included them
column25: then the numbers would be much worse.    First there is the propaganda technique of "everybody's doing it": "AA or a similar Twelve-Step program is an integral part of almost all successful recoveries".  That is a complete falsehood. The vast majority of the successful people recover without A.A. or any "support group". It's what "everybody" is doing.  Then they use the propaganda techniques of use of the passive voice and vague suggestions: "It is widely believed that not including a Twelve-Step program in a treatment plan can put a recovering addict on the road to relapse."  It is widely believed by whom? And what do those unnamed people know? What are their qualifications? Are they doctors? Medical school professors? Or salesmen for a 12-Step treatment center? Why should we care what some unnamed invisible fools allegedly believe
column26: anyway?  The authors also use the propaganda technique of fear-mongering: you will be "on the road to relapse" -- you will probably die -- unless you practice Bill Wilson's Twelve Step cult religion.  And then the fluff-headed Pollyanna attitude is outrageous: Just going to the wonderful A.A. meetings is supposedly all that is needed to fix some alcoholics.  But since A.A. has a zero-percent success rate above and beyond the normal rate of spontaneous remission
column27: that cannot possibly be true.

column1: The cover of this film says "If you loved THE MISSION and THE APOSTLE(which I did!) then you will LOVE MOLOKAI!"........Sorry....I didn't!This film cannot even begin to be compared with those wonderful films.Paul Cox's direction of such talent as Sir Derek Jacobi and Peter O'Toole is an utter travesty.David Wenham is positively laughable as Father Damien.The screenplay dialogue is sheer dribble and the film is as static as static can be.What SHOULD have been a riveting retelling of Hawaii's "dirty little secret" is reduced to pure nonsense and cliche deplorably acted by all parties.Even the breathtaking cinematography of the Hawaiian Islands (which was minimal at best) could not bring salvation to  this leperous bore!Even the film BLACKROBE was better than this

column1: Season three of Enterprise is one of the primary reasons the show was cancelled.  Ratings dropped during this season and the announcement of the show's cancellation came before the superior season 4 could save it.  The problem with season three is that nearly every episode deals directly with the Xindi threat.  Long story arcs have happened in Star Trek before
column2: such as the Dominion Wars in DS9.  The problem with the Xindi arc is that there are too few "change of pace" episodes.  Having three out of every four episodes about the same stroyline is boring.  There was not enough variety in this season.  It became quite redundant and I was quite happy when it ended.  Plus
column3: there was no real suspense.  It was obvious that Earth was not going to be destroyed
column4: so the outcome was not enough to keep one on the seat of his/her pants.  Season 4 was much better
column5: but unfortunately couldn't save the show.  The idea of shorter story arcs was excellent
column6: given the poor ratings they got in the previous season.  These mini-arcs were somewhat unique in the world of Star Trek
column7: but worked much better than the mega-arc that was season 3

column1: After reading the book Medicine Woman and the San Francisco Review of Books on the back which says this is an Autobiographical I have to question a few things.     I come from Manitoba and have lived there over 50 years.  I've never heard of a Crowley and the Cree First Nations in Manitoba that I was raised with would not be seeing a Kokopelli or a Kachina.  It's not part of their culture.  The last and final huge mistake is the fact that most of this story could not have taken place outside without huge huge bottles of mosquitoe repellant as anyone who lives in the bush in Manitoba knows especially those who may have a reason to go naked in the woods.  Perhaps Lynn shouldn't be peddling her strange brand of spiritualism as true when it's not.  There are enough charlatans in the world without one stealing someone's culture and calling it her own for the sake of the almight dollar.    Carol

column1: I received Turner's book "The Hidden World of Birthdays" and Gary Goldschneider's book
column2: "The Secret Langugage of Birthdays" as Christmas presents. I became fascinated with the subject after reading Goldschneider's book years ago in a library
column3: which seemed accurate to me.   I had similar high hopes for Turner's book. I thought it would be an in depth study of astrology and birthdays. Her study is advice that
column4: in my opinion
column5: could be found online or in any book about astrology. The personality profiles she gives for each birthday is general
column6: unhelpful and sometimes stupid. For example
column7: on one birthday she gives the advice
column8: of "Health Scent: Lavender--This scent might lead others to trust you and make you patient." Excuse me
column9: but how can a specific scent lead others to trust you more? Or
column10: on another she gives the Possessions and Desires
column11: "Crocus: You may spend too much time stewing over those who have innocently harmed you." Turner doesn't give an explanation for why each of these flowers
column12: charms
column13: or colors are right for each birthday.   Turner doesn't give any historical background for why certain stones
column14: numbers
column15: etc; would be good for one birthday as opposed to another. Nor does she explain how she develops the numerological numbers for each birthday. Another thing noticeably absent from Turner's book is that she doesn't have any descriptions about each one of the astrological signs or their "element" (i.e. fire
column16: water
column17: earth
column18: air) and how they relate to one another.  In fact
column19: Turner's book was so bad
column20: the person who gave me the gift initially told me to trash it.   One might ask why I'm being so harsh on Turner? It's because I believe she's borrowed the "personology" premise from Gary Goldschneider and Joost Elffers in "The Secret Language of Birthdays" who do a much better job than she does. Each profile is more in depth
column21: and they include names of famous people born on your birthday
column22: as well as meditations
column23: numerological and tarot cards related to your birthday profile
column24: as well as specific explanations of how they developed them. At the beginning of Goldschneider's book there are definitions/personality traits of each specific astrological sign. Each sign is then divided into four groups (which includes the "cusp" group) and with personality traits and advice for each group. For example
column25: Virgo is divided into Virgo I
column26: Virgo II
column27: Virgo III and the Virgo-Libra Cusp. It includes information about colors
column28: plants
column29: foods
column30: composers
column31: etc; attractions
column32: and life path "themes" for each sign and the stage of human life that every sign represents. There's also an astrological chart included and an index to look up famous people and their birthdays. Turner's book has a few of these features
column33: along with angels for each birth date
column34: but no explanatory notes about why they're used for each day.  If you're looking for a great astrological study
column35: there is no comparison:  skip Turner's book altogether and go with Goldschneider and Elffers's "The Secret Language of Birthdays."

column1: Before I start
column2: let me nail my colours to the mast: I'm pro-science
column3: I'm pro-evolution
column4: I really like the idea of rational enquiry and I'm a sceptic bordering on the cynical. I'm *not* some lentil-munching
column5: kaftan-wearing
column6: feng-shui-hugging hippie with airbrushed unicorns and a yin-yang sign on the side of my Kombi. Honestly.  Now we've got that cleared up
column7: let me say it straight: This book takes on some big arguments
column8: but
column9: other than humorously swatting some flies
column10: loses hands down. All it succeeds in doing is illustrating that there are fakers
column11: losers
column12: charlatans and wankers to be found in the Social Sciences departments of any given University. Anyone who's been to university and didn't know that deserves a clip around the ear and to be sent to the back of the class. Now either Sokal didn't know that ( - ~clip~ -)
column13: or he's spent half his book shooting fish in a barrel. That might seem like good sport
column14: but before long it becomes obvious it's a cheap thrill.  Having said that
column15: I sincerely doubt that the titillation of seeing dumb French Feminists taken apart is what made this book such a splash: I think it's because of Sokal's purported intent: to undermine the notion of cognitive relativism
column16: especially as it associated with modern philosophy of science
column17: in particular the work of Thomas Kuhn and Paul Feyerabend. This is the battle: Sokal aligns with those who say scientists are the exclusive purveyors of a shining light called truth; the Barbarians at the gate are these simpering postmodernists who want to tear the temple down.  While the poseurs cited in this book are certainly (for the most part) phoneys or idiots
column18: I think Thomas Kuhn was neither
column19: and while Paul Feyerabend overplayed the court jester hand
column20: he had some important things to say too.  So
column21: to the first point: Proving that one writer (or a hundred
column22: or a thousand) who purports to adhere to relativism is a charlatan doesn't establish anything about *the idea* of relativism. All you have established is that you have a found yourself a charlatan. Give yourself a star.   But while you're pinning it on
column23: remember that postmodernists do not have a monopoly on illogical
column24: bamboozling
column25: balderdash:  Example: Sir Roger Penrose (Emeritus Rouse Ball professor of mathematics at Oxford University
column26: no less) and his dreadful
column27: lumpen-headed
column28: and deliberately bamboozling anti-AI tract "The Emperor's New Mind". The very point of the (no doubt correct but nonetheless entirely irrelevant) science deluged on the reader in that book is to obscure the fact that the real emperor was Roger Penrose and his arguments on AI really blow the kumara.   Example: Noam Chomsky and Steven Pinker's Linguistic Nativism
column29: which has held sway for a good thirty years in many linguistics departments
column30: and is anything but post-modern: nativism holds that humans have an innate understanding of grammar hard wired into their biology. From my paltry readings in linguistics and the philosophy of language
column31: my impression is that Pinker's and Chomsky's arguments are seriously flawed. (See: Sampson: "The Language Instinct Debate" for a thorough linguistic critique of nativism; see Rorty: "Contingency Irony
column32: and Solidarity" for a philosophical perspective on the contingency of language). Make note of this example
column33: as it becomes relevant later on.  Secondly
column34: Sokal and Bricmont (quite deliberately) refuse to engage on certain topics
column35: in particular on cultural or aesthetic relativism
column36: which they say (without providing a reason) "raise very different issues". Take that star away
column37: for this statement betrays a fundamental misunderstanding about relativism. Actually
column38: ethical
column39: aesthetic and cognitive relativisms raise different manifestations of *exactly* the same issue: Cognitive relativism
column40: in that it relates to "epistemic" truth (as opposed to "moral" truth or "aesthetic" truth - both of which seem intuitively more questionable ideas) is simply a cut closer to the quick: indeed
column41: the aesthetic and moral brands of relativism rely for their plausibility on cognitive relativism anyway (i.e. if the truths we understand about the physical universe are contingent on our language
column42: then it follows that ideals of right and wrong and beauty must be similarly contingent on our language).  Thirdly
column43: Sokal provides the following account of cognitive relativism:   "While scientists ... try to obtain an objective view ... of the world
column44: relativist thinkers tell them that they are wasting their time and that such an enterprise is
column45: in principle
column46: an illusion"  Now that
column47: to put it mildly
column48: is a *very* punchy version of relativism
column49: and not one that any credible relativist philosopher I know of (and certainly not Thomas Kuhn
column50: who spent a whole book explaining how and why the process scientific discovery works) subscribes to.  That is
column51: in the trade
column52: known as a straw-man argument: You set it up to knock it over. Here goes:   P1: Relativists say science is a waste of time P2: Science helps us reliably predict and react coherently to phenomena occurring in the world  P3: Things which help to predict and react to such phenomena have genuine utility  C1: Therefore
column53: science has genuine utility C2: Ergo
column54: science is not a waste of time  Case closed. Is relativism dead? No: the problem is
column55: most relativists I know would completely agree with all of the above argument except for premise 1. The cat is most definitely still out of the bag. (In a nutshell
column56: all reasonably stated relativism says is that you can't know that your theory actually maps onto the actual configuration of the outside world; it may
column57: it may not: logically there will always be some other possible explanation for the same set of data
column58: however implausible or difficult to imagine
column59: and in part that difficulty in imagination may be a function of the historical contingency of our belief in
column60: and description of the world in terms of
column61: the current "paradigm". Relativism simply says the best you can do is to know that
column64: not that it is *true*. Though Sokal and Bricmont may disagree
column65: I don't think this is controversial amongst philosophers nor
column68: in criticising an admittedly utterly ludicrous passage bestowed on the world by that splendidly silly feminist philosopher Sylvia Kristeva
column69: Sokal makes the following footnote:  "...Kristeva seems to be appealing ... to the 'Sapir-Whorf thesis' in linguistics that is ...that our language radically conditions our view of the world. This thesis nowadays is sharply criticised by some linguists: see
column70: for example Pinker ..."  Hold the phone. The implication is that the Sapir-Whorf thesis (as to the contingency of language) has been discredited
column71: but by none other than Steven Pinker in his "The Language Instinct" which
column73: is at the very least a controversial piece of writing. This is an extremely important point
column74: since it's utterly central to the credibility of the anti-relativist cause
column75: and if one takes Geoffrey Sampson's book (cited above) at face value the nativist claims themselves are built on very suspect reasoning and scientific research. It seems to me (and to writers like Richard Rorty) that language must radically condition our view of the world
column76: because that's the only basis on which we can even describe it.  At the end of the day
column77: properly stated cognitive relativism is no a threat to modern scientific discourse
column78: except that it relegates the scientist from "truth knower" or "person through whom you may have exclusive access to the truth" (sounds a bit like a grand high pooh-bah or - dare I say it - high priest
column79: doesn't it?) to "person whose theory works the best for now" and who may be in competition for that status with other people in the community whether or not they're scientists.   If science *does* work better than feng shui or healing crystals (and I
column81: think it does) then this shouldn't be a particularly troubling way of looking at the world for a scientist who is at ease with his views and his value to the community. So it makes the knee-jerk reactions against relativism
column82: from the likes of Sokal and elsewhere Richard Dawkins
column83: all the more mystifying.  Olly Buxton

column1: Like W.D. I felt that the novel was lengthy with characters that simply cluttered the landscape. Tragedy after tragedy unfolds: a kidnapping of an ellitist; a run on a bank; a near-stock market crash; Hong Kong's world-famous floating restaurant catches fire
column2: burns
column3: and sinks; a mud-slide that destroys a prominent hotel; a chinese-communist espionage plot; a soviet espionage plot; secret-agents
column4: double-agents

column6: but the reader loses sense of the time since the book is so time consuming. I was fascinated with Clavell's Taipan and was further interested in the exploits of the Struan family. This was a disppointment! Dunross
column7: the present Taipan
column8: moves through novel with a killer business instinct and brief instances of compassion and humanity. Why does he do it? He is trying to live up to a legacy. That's it. In one sentence that is as deep as Dunross goes. The novel Taipan was so different in development of its characters. Dunross'one-sentence purpose for living
column9: when contrasted with Dirk Struan's vision of the Noble House helping China become a world power was completely lacking. Clavell's earlier work was very insightful about China especially in its potential influence. However
column10: the parade of characters in Noble House is similar to a chinese all-you-can-eat buffet restaurant: plenty of food
column11: but lacking in authentic taste. Overall the work was very tiring and uninspiring. Nothing noble about it at all.

column1: This book uses a canon to kill a flea.  Sympathetic as I am to the rhetorical and discursive analysis of cultural formations
column2: such a project requires depth and context to be intelligible:  this book lacks both.  It provides quick parachute drops into various aspects of discursively mediated marketeering strategies touching on discourse touching on the body
column3: and then hurries on to another example or arena without working through the consequences of the argument.  Morever
column4: the style is ponderous enough to kill a child with lead poisoning.  Since the author never bothers to ask who reads (let alone who is persuaded by) the discursive constructs that she so rapidly catalogues
column5: one wonders why she has devoted all this energy to debunking notions that are probably believed by virtually no one

column1: The book is not well written.  The author does not clearly explain her thinking

column3: and always assumes that the reader has some working knowledge on the matter she is writing about.  That is not to say that the book cannot be useful.  The author has some good points on why technical analysis can work
column4: but it is a petty that more often than not her message does not come across.

column1: I'm a novelist
column2: and this book did not live up to my expectations. Most of the book was written for non-fiction writers.  I've read other query letter guides
column3: which advise authors to  - avoid using opinion to describe your own work (such as 'fast-paced') - avoid using adjectives and adverbs to describe the story  And Mr. Wood agrees. In the short section on novel queries
column4: he includes three examples of query letters that got the attention of their new agents or publishers. Two of them broke these rules.   Mr. Wood proposes that we write a query such that editors and agents sit up and take notice
column5: yet he does not explain how to do this without breaking the 'commandments.' So
column6: if he agrees with the rules
column7: but includes examples of query letters that break them
column8: what's an author supposed to think? My conclusion is that Mr. Wood has no better idea than I do what constitutes a good query letter.  I'll continue my search for a good book on writing query letters. This is not it

column1: I have heard a lot about Richard Matheson
column2: and when I found out he'd written a survivalist fiction story (a favorite sub-genre of mine)I was elated to read it.  However
column3: after a long arduous struggle to continue reading
column4: I realized that disappointment and madness are quite connected.  "Hunted Past Reason" tells the story of two men: Doug and Bob.  Bob
column5: a writer
column6: wants to write a novel of backpacking.  Doug
column7: the expert
column8: is more than happy to teach him the tricks of the trade.  Right from the start
column9: we are privy to the personality clash between the two.  Doug starts out as a "know it all" to Bob.  He tries to bludgeon Bob with his vast knowledge of the wilderness.   As the story progresses
column10: we see Doug's jealousy of Bob's successful career and family life come to the surface.  I must admit that the subtle changes in Doug are blended very well into the story.  On the other hand
column11: the story was dragged out far too long than necessary.  After philosophical discussions between the two (which are strained at best)
column12: we see Doug's deep seated sociopathic tendencies which erupt into a game of cat and mouse between the two.  After a graphic rape scene
column13: Doug gives Bob a three hour head start and thus the story turns into "Deliverance" (as quite a few readers in this very forum have pointed out).  The writing seems to be quite repetitive.  The mental conversations between Bob and his subconscious provide for filler and are thinly veiled attempts at drawing the suspense out.  Being a fan of this type of subgenre of fiction
column14: I was mildly entertained by the reading
column15: however
column16: I expected a bit more from Matheson (simply because of his fame and influence he's had on other writers ).  Maybe I was a bit unfair
column17: but the other reviews tell me otherwise

column1: There is nothing wrong with the form of this documentary: It is well presented with great CGIs
column2: narration and overall structure - hence it is worth at least two stars (whatever this stars rating business means).  The problem is the substance: it is simply not there. Menzies is one of those pseudo-scientists (as he is indirectly described by one of his opponents) that are in love with their own baseless theory and are not prepared to question its validity regardless of the absence of evidence corroborating it or the presence of evidence contradicting it.  I think a true scientist should not be emotionally attached to any theory and should simply be involved with the process of discovering evidence. Menzies
column3: starts off with his conclusion (rather than ending with it) and fumbles his way backwards trying to find evidence to support it. When all alleged evidence is demolished
column4: he arrogantly states that he will not budge
column5: "one millimetre" as he puts it
column6: from his theory and that
column7: in time
column8: everyone will accept it as a fact that the Chinese were the first to discover America.  A true scientist
column9: even in the presence of evidence substantiating his/her viewpoint
column10: always keeps an open mind and is prepared to accept the eventuality that they may be proved wrong in the future. Menzies does exactly the opposite: with no evidence on his side
column11: he refuses to admit even for a second that he just may be wrong.  It saddens me that by simply engaging in what is nothing short of unsubstantiated verbal diarrhoea
column12: Menzies - not a scientist but
column13: at best
column14: a qualified mariner - managed to make a buck on his book and that PBS
column15: helped him earn some more on the back of his childish theory by making a documentary on him. The feeling one gets at the end
column16: is that PBS ran out of ideas for their next production and decided to make a meal out of this chap's air-ology.  Whilst visually pleasing
column17: this PBS production is in substance a waste of time to watch
column18: as it is neither educating nor troubling the mind of the viewer

column1: It is not so much that I did not think the plot plausable
column2: but the characterizations are untrue to the original book.  I feel not enough time and care was taken to move the plot within the parameters of the characters as set by JA.  Miss Darcy
column3: although entertaining
column4: becomes a pale shade of Elizabeth Bennett.  Lady Catherine becomes flaccidly comic (has she become a vicar or even transposed with Mr Collins?)  It pains me also to see the most interesting and engaging characters of Elizabeth and Darcy pushed so far into the background.  I also take issue with the use of Lizzy and Fitzwilliam as the familiar names the couple uses when refering to each other.  I am almost certain that Elizabeth would always be Elizabeth in Darcy's eyes and that none of the characters in P&P would have used anything but Darcy's surname.  All of this censure aside
column5: it was a good attempt.  I thought the phrasing and meter of the work to pay homage to Austen.  I also admire the care taken in research of the subject matter and time period.  I would recommend this book as what it is aptly titled ":An Entertainment"

column1: This is pitiful. How do you maximize profit? Easy
column2: minimize quality on every level and capitalize on the brand name. In other words
column3: raise expectations through the roof with a superior detective series and use this momentum to sell an inferior follow-up series under the same name.   Ghost in the Shell 2nd Gig says "Cheap" from the opening credit montage to the bare bone ending credits. The colors
column4: unlike the first season's which were deep and juicy

column10: from Batou to Kusanagi have been altered considerably. Kusanagi's eyes are bigger and her body seems shorter and less voluptuous. Batou's arms are shorter. The lean
column11: chiseled features of Aramaki which made him appear old and wise are now younger and fuller. The mecha and weapons in this series are also vague. The individual eleven are not as interesting as the laughing man plot of the first season's series.   I had high hopes for this series. column8: "Although these data are well over 20 years old
column9: they remain applicable in a modern context" ... So absurd !!! Does the author mean that the Software Engineering discipline has failed to such an extent that the software industry (in general) is as bad as it was 20 years ago.    3. The organization of the book is pretty bad.  There are too many quotes
column10: WebRefs
column11: KeyPoints.  Some of the quotes are good
column12: but many a times out of context. And when I think of it
column13: one can publish "Quote of the day" kind of a column for more than a year using this book! (not a bad reason to buy a book ... unintented consequences ... it's like a defect in the software which is declared as a feature)   4. And finally
column14: there is neither anything new nor anything original in this book.    The best advice I could find in this book was more applicable to the author than anybody else. And the advice is in the form of a quote at the end of the section 26.1.4. "It takes less time to do a thing right than to explain why you did it wrong   - H.W.Longfellow"     Dear Author
column15: the readers deserve an explanation!

If you are looking for an IPod alarm system this is your machine.  The reviewer comments about good sound quality are on the mark.  But it has one serious design flaw at least for how I wanted to use it and I'm returning mine.  I thought it was a dual IPod/Radio alarm system
column2: as advertised.  It is not.  The radio alarm is only a second alarm
column3: apparently for a second sleeper.  You cannot select between the two options. Tried the work around of setting the second alarm to go off first but you can't not set Ipod alarm so when it (or the buzzer) goes off it shuts down the radio.  Can't understand why they couldn't have worked around this issue but beware if you want choice and flexibility in what you wake to.

column1: The author cannot seem to grasp that there is much discontent amongst the people. She swallows the Islamic doublespeak about women's rights but I'm sure she wouldn't tolerate one tenth of what Iranian women must endure. Also she is fixated on being a blonde in Iran. Weird
Black and Blue is the story of a woman who flees an abusive relationship
column2: taking her son and attempting to disappear into residential Florida
column3: all the while waiting for her husband
column4: a New York cop
column5: to find and hurt her. The book is not Quindlen's best and while it is readable
column6: and at less than 400 pages a manageable length
column7: it feels like little more than a Lifetime "woman's" movie in novel form. I wouldn't recommend this book
column8: especially in comparison to Quindlen's other work
column9: although the lessons of what abuse is
column10: how it happens
column11: and how difficult it can be to escape are good ones to learn about
column12: even in a fictional context.  Anna Quindlen is also the author of One True Thing
column13: a book-cum-film about a daughter's experience with her mother's terminal cancer. That book is good--realistic
column14: emotional but not maudlin
column15: and challenging. Black and Blue is merely an example of weak writing that reads like a made-for-TV movie. It made its way into Oprah's book club but would never make it on to  my must-read lists. Facing the realities of abuse is a good lesson to learn
column16: and so the subject is worth reading about
column17: but Quindlen's portrayal is less than realistic or compelling. All of the checklist facts are there: abuse leads to abuse
column18: specifically carried from father to son; some women are drawn to the type of men that are/become abusers; legal protection can be inadequate; violence can lead to death. So on
column19: so forth. The list of facts is there but the emotional context is filmsy
column20: centers on children (rather than personal strength) and strange
column21: powerless situations. Even when she flees her husband
column22: things seem to be done to the protagonist rather than done by her. It's unfulfilling and disappointing to the reader and detracts from the whole text. In fact
column23: the more interesting characters are mere foils and supporting roles like her new friends and romantic interest. They seem to have more personality and depth than the protagonist.  It will take less time and energy
column24: and induce the same emotional responce
column25: to watch any one of the numerous women's TV daytime movies about the same subject. Black and Blue is gripping only because you want to know if her husband will find her or not
column26: and presents very few challenges
column27: either in the writing or the ideas
column28: to the reader. It's readable and I was able to get through it
column29: but it's still a poor example of literature and even of the lesson it attempts to teach. Don't waste your time on this one

column1: After reading this book
column2: I would like to make three points about it:  1.) First of all
column3: DON'T MAKE THIS YOUR FIRST DEAN KOONTZ BOOK.  This is the second book of the so-called Christopher Snow trilogy.  Read the first book in the trilogy first -- FEAR NOTHING.  The first book introduces pretty much all the key characters that you find in this book.  2.) Second
column4: please be aware that Koontz has yet to write the third book in the Christopher Snow trilogy.  This is a real shame
column5: because SEIZE THE NIGHT ends on a cliffhanger of sorts.  Koontz has claimed that he will write the third book someday
column6: under the title RIDE THE STORM.  But since it's been over eight years since Koontz has written a Snow novel
column7: I wouldn't expect this book anytime soon.    3.) Third
column8: I must admit I didn't really care for this book at all
column9: and I say that as a Koontz fan.  Lots of padding -- the action doesn't really start until page 250.  Koontz wastes a LOT of space repeating things he originally wrote in FEAR NOTHING.   I found myself skipping through this book quite a bit to get to the good parts.  The plot here is also too over the top -- plot elements include time travel
column10: killer monkeys
column11: alternate realities
column12: serial killers conducting government experiments -- and that's just the tip of the iceberg!  Even the characters in the book don't seem to take any of it seriously.  All the dialogue in this book is whimsical and unrealistic.  I was therefore never able to suspend disbelief for this book.  It was just too silly for my tastes.  Koontz is a great writer
column13: but his best novels are the ones that have a more believable
column14: fast-paced plot.  Instead of this book
column15: I would therefore recommend WATCHERS
column16: INTENSITY
column17: ODD THOMAS or VELOCITY.

column1: Love the topic and a lot of what Schmitt has to say
column2: but have significant issues with the style
column3: language and presentation.  The book's style is neither fish-nor-fowl
column4: but occupies a middle ground between science fiction
column5: an academic paper and a powerpoint presentation.  It largely reads like an academic paper
column6: with countless footnotes (oddly placed at the end of each chapter
column7: not at the end of the book) and a writing style that's hard to folow unless you are willing to find a pen & paper to take notes while you read.   In this sense it resembles the guise of a very dry academic paper - which would be fine
column8: but at the same time it also lacks the focus and precision of an academic paper.   Previous comments have focused on some of the perceived inacuracies in  across some the many specialized fields he touches
column9: including: - fussion reactors
column10: - mining technologies  - exogeology
column11: - economics
column12: - long-term energy predictions
column13: - spaceflight
column14: - management theory
column15: - International relations - etc..  He certainly deserves praise for the amount of time and effort he has spent becoming conversant in all those diverse disciplines
column16: but his presentation of each individual one is typically dry and often unequal to the complexity of the subject matter.  Finally
column17: my primary issue with his approach is that it's based on a strange & uneasy mixture of private enterprise and Apollo-style government science projects.    Substitute taxpayers for investors
column18: and you have much the same approach - various people representing multiple constituencies gathered around a conference table
column19: a strategic plan
column20: and a massive pool of cash to be deployed in pursuit of this plan.   It just doesnt work that way - no large company started life *as* a large company
column21: and certainly not as a large company with a plan.   If/when we do see He-3 mining on the moon
column22: it will come about as an organic process
column23: with carpetbaggers
column24: prospectors
column25: conflicting claims
column26: unrelated developments
column27: lawsuits
column28: booms and busts
column29: lucky breaks
column30: etc..

column1: I am not a doctor or nutritionist
column2: but nutrition is a subject that interests me. If I
column3: as a layperson
column4: were to write a book about this subject I would dive into the internet and read a bunch of articles and come up with probably similar conclusions as this author. Unfortunately
column5: the science and the studies of nutrition is not that simple to interpret. The majority of nutritional studies are flawed and unless you are an expert in the field you cannot easily determine the accuracy of the study  or the conclusions that are made. Reading articles about studies
column6: rather than the studies themself is probably the worst thing to base a conclusion off of and write a book about
column7: which the author(and most authors) seems to do here
column8: based on his opinionated writing and nonscientific conclusions. Some of the information in this book is correct and some is not. The other problem I have is that the author doesn't seem to have any experience with patients of any of the topics he writes about. For instance
column9: he really slams flouride
column10: most of which I agree with. But many dentists and people I have talked to claim that fluoride really does work for the teeth. Maybe injesting it is unnecessary
column11: but rubbing it on the teeth seems to be good. He also says fish oil supplements and some vitamin supplements are beneficial. That is not accurate either. Most oil supplements are sold in a rancid state because they are not refrigerated and 99.99% of vitamins are just chemicals which offer no improvement in health or prevention of disease. He also says cholesterol has nothing to do with getting heart disease (I'm paraphrasing). Most cardiologist would agree that cholesterol does not cause heart disease
column12: but numerous studies show a direct correlation between high cholesterol and heart disease. As my cardiologist put it "The inflammation is the fire
column13: the cholesterol is the fuel." Those are just a few of the many inaccuracies. The real unfortunate thing about this book is that it does not help you "find reality in the mire of food industry propoganda" as the title claims. It leaves you more confused. Even his conclusion is that he doesn't really know what the best diet is and that everybody is different and should have different diets. Uh
column14: ok
column15: thanks for nothing. I would recommend to anyone interested in nutrition to read "Eat to Live" by Dr. Joel Fuhrman. He seems to be a more credible expert on nutrition and has much experience with patience to back up his conclusions. If you want a good book regarding politics and nutrition
column16: check out "The China Study".

column1: The mere act of arguing that comic art qualifies as "fine art" somehow legitimizes such nonproductive and ultimately meaningless distinctions. Yet this catalogue's obvious purpose is to somehow elevate
column2: by force of such argument
column3: the reputations of comic strip and comic book artists. As the early twentieth century cultural critic
column4: Gilbert Seldes
column5: stated in his review of George Herriman's Krazy Kat:  	Krazy Kat
column6: the daily comic strip of George Herriman is
column7: to me
column8: the most amusing and fantastic and satisfactory 	work of art produced in America today.  With those who 	hold that a comic strip cannot be a work of art
column9: I shall 	not traffic.   Not only is it unlikely that this book of self-promoting essays
column10: largely written by comic artists
column11: will advance the position of comic art within the insular and rarified world of contemporary art criticism
column12: the book does not even go far enough to promote the appreciation of the genre among those readers/viewers with a genuine interest in the art form.   The presentation of comic strip art is certainly worthy of attention
column13: despite the glaring exclusion of any significant discussion of the two giants of adventure strip art
column14: Alex Raymond and Hal Foster. But the quality of the strip art which is included speaks so loudly that the written commentary can be largely ignored in evaluating the artistic merits.  Ironically
column15: the authors' verbose analyses of modern comic book art will probably fall on more sympathetic ears
column16: despite the fact that  most of the artists chosen as representative of American comic book art would not even be considered by most comic book aficionados as top contenders for inclusion in a comic art exhibition.  But
column17: then again
column18: that is probably why these "graphic novel" and underground comic book artists were selected -- they produce the type of art that is most likely to appeal to the gimmick sensibility of contemporary art critics.  When judged by more traditional (some would say old-fashion) standards of artistic excellence
column19: such as quality of draftsmanship and composition
column20: it is hard to see how most of these artists have produced even good art
column21: let alone "fine art."  But
column22: perhaps like the child who could not see the emperor's new clothes
column23: some viewers just are not sophisticated enough to fully understand or appreciate fine contemporary comic book art.  If you fall into this category
column24: then this is the perfect book for you.  CRAIG W.  ENGLUND
